editorialDecl.p: The characters are identified by IDREF pointing to information in the following declarations. Robert Hood Servant Skink Old King Gloucester Young King Prince Richard Sir Richard Falconbridge Prince John Lancaster Leicester Officer Keeper Redcap Constable Block Lady Falconbridge Queen Porter Drawer Pursuivant Page Sherriff More than one character speaking at once Musician Voice off

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by idREF which point to the following.

div1.stage: Enter Robert Hood a young Noble-man, a seruant with him, with ryding wandes in theyr handes, as if they had beene new lighted.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.l: Go, walk the horses, wait me on the hill,
This is the Hermits Cell, go out of sight:
My business with him must not be revealed,
To any mortal creature but himself.

sp.speaker: Seru.
sp.l: I will wait your honour in the cross high-way.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Do so: Hermit devout and reverend,
If drowsy age keep not thy stiffened joints,
On thy unrestful bed, or if the hours
Of holy Orisons detain thee not,
Come forth.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: Good morrow son, good morrow, and God bless thee Huntington,
A brighter Gleam of true Nobility
Shines not in any youth more than in thee.
Thou shalt be rich in honour, full of speed,
Thou shalt win foes by fear, and friends by meed.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Father, I come not now to know my fate,
Important business urgeth Princely Richard ,
In these terms to salute thy reverend age.
Read and be brief, I know some cause of trust,
Made him employ me for his messenger.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: A cause of trust indeed true honoured youth,
Princes had need in matters of import,
To make nice choice fair Earl, if I not err,
Thou art the Princes ward.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Father I am his ward, his Chamberlain and bedfellow.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: Fair fall thee honourable Robert Hood ,
Wend to Prince Richard , say though I am loath,
To use my skill in Conjuration:
Yet Skink that poisoned red cheeked Rosamond ,
Shall make appearance at the Parliament,
He shall be there by noon assure his Grace.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Good morrow Father, see you fail him not,
For though the villain did a horrible deed,
Yet hath the young King Richard , and Earl Iohn ,
Sworn to defend him from his greatest foes.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: Gods benison be with thee noble Earl.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Adieu good father, holla there, my horse?

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: Up, spur the kicking Jade, while I make speed
To Conjure Skink out of his Hermits weed;
Lie there religion keep thy Master grave,
And on the fair trust of these Princes word
To Court again Skink: but before I go,
Let mischief take advise of villainy,
Why to the Hermit letters should be sent,
To post Skink to the Court incontinent:
Is there no trick in this? ha let me see?
Or do they know already I am he?
If they do so, faith westward then with Skink:
But what an ass am I to be thus fond,
Here lies the Hermit whom I dying found
Some two months since, when I was hourly charged
With Hugh the Crier and with Constables,
I saw him in the ready way to heaven,
I helped him forward, it was a holy deed;
And there he lies some six foot in the ground,
Since when, and since, I kept me in his weeds.
O what a world of fools have filled my Cell;
For Fortunes, run-aways, stolen goods, lost cattle,
Among the number, all the faction
That take the young Kings part against the old;
Come to myself to hearken for myself,
So did the adverse party make enquire,
But either fall full of contrary desire:
The old Kings part would kill me being stained,
The young Kings keep me from their violence.
So then thou needst not fear, go boldly on,
Brave Hall , Prince Dicke , and my spruce hot spur John ,
Here is their safe conduct: O but for Rosamond !
A fig for Rosamond to this hope I will lean:
At a Queens bidding I did kill a quean.

div1.stage: Sound Trumpets, enter with a Harrald on the one side, Henry the second Crowned, after him Lancaster, Chester, Sir Richard Faukenbridge: on the other part, K. Henry the Sonne crowned, Herrald after him: after him Prince Rich. Iohn, Leyster, being set, enters fantasticall Robert of Gloster in a gowne girt: walkes vp and downe.

sp.speaker: Old. K.
sp.l: Why doth not Gloucester take his honoured seat?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Infaith my Liege Gloucester is in a land
Where neither surety is to sit or stand.
I only do appear as I am summoned,
And will await without till I am called.

sp.speaker: Yon. K.
sp.l: Why hear you Gloucester ?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Henry I do hear you.

sp.speaker: Yon. K.
sp.l: And why not King?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: What is he that sits so near you?

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: King too.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Two Kings? ha ha.

sp.speaker: Ol. K.
sp.l: Gloucester sit we charge thee.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: I will obey your charge, I will sit down,
But in this house, on no seat but the ground.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: The seat is too good.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: I know it brother Iohn.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Thy brother?

sp.speaker: Ol. K.
sp.l: Silence there.

sp.speaker: Yon. K.
sp.l: Pass to the bills Sir Richard Falconbridge .

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: My Lieges both, old Falconbridge is proud
Of your right honoured charge. He that worst may
Will strain his old eyes, God send peace this day.
A bill for the releasement of the Queen preferred,
By Henry the young King, Rich. the Prince, John Earl
Of Murton, Bohmine Earl of Leister and the commons:

sp.speaker: Old K.
sp.l: Did you prefer this bill?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: We did.

sp.speaker: Chest., Lanc.
sp.l: Ye did not well.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Why this is good now shall we have the hell.

sp.speaker: 3. Bro.
sp.l: Chester and Lanchaster you wrong the King.

sp.speaker: Chest., Lan.
sp.l: Our King we do not.

sp.speaker: Yon. K.
sp.l: Do not you see me crowned?

sp.speaker: Lanc.
sp.l: But whilst he lives we to none else are bound.

sp.speaker: Ley:
sp.l: Is it not wrong think you, when all the world
Troubled with rumour of a captive Queen,
Imprisoned by her husband in a Realm,
Where her own son doth wear a Diadem?
Is like an head of people mutinous.
Still murmuring at the shame done her and us?
Is it not more wrong when her mother zeal
Sounded through Europe, Africa, Asia,
Tells in the hollow of news thirsting ears,
Queen Elinor lives in a dungeon,
For pity and affection to her son:
But when the true cause, Cliffords daughters death
Shall be exposed to stranger nations:
What volumes will be writ, what libels spread?
And in each line our state dishonoured.

sp.speaker: Fauk.
sp.l: My Lord speaks to the purpose, marry it may be so,
Pray God it prove not so.

sp.speaker: Ley.
sp.l: Hear me conclude, and there withal conclude,
It is an heinous and unheard of sin:
Queen Elinor daughter to Kingly France,
King Henries wife and royal Henries mother,
Is kept close prisoner for an act of Justice,
Committed on an odious Concubine,

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Thou wrongst her Leister .

sp.speaker: Lei.
sp.l: Lechers ever praise the cause of their confusion, she was vile

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: She was ill spoken of it is, true, true.

sp.speaker: Glosr.
sp.l: Yonder sits one would do as much for you
Old fool, young Richard hath a gift I know it,
And on your wife my sister would bestow it.
Here is a good world men hate adulterous sin,
Count it a gulf, and yet they needs will in.

sp.speaker: Lei.
sp.l: What answer for the Queen?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: The King replies your words are foul slanderous forgeries.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: His highness says not so.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: His highness doth,
Tells you it is a shame for such wild youth,
To smother any impiety,
With show to chastise loose adultery.
Say Rosamond was Henries Concubine,
Had never King a Concubine but he?
Did Rosamond begin the fires in France?
Made she the Northern borders reek with flames?
Unpeopled she the towns of Picardy?
Left she the wives of England husbandless?
O no: she sinned I grant, so do we all,
She fell herself, desiring none should fall;
But Elinor whom you so much commend,
Hath been the bellows of seditious fire,
Either through Jealous rage or mad desire;
Is it not a shame to think that she hath armed
Four Sons right hands, against their fathers head,
And not the children of a low-prized wretch,
But one whom God on earth hath deified?
See where he sits with sorrow in his eyes,
Three of his Sons and hers tutored by her,
Smiles whilst he weeps, and with a proud disdain,
Embrace blithe mirth, while his sad heart complain.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Ha laugh they? nay by the rood that is not well,
Now fie young Princes fie.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Peace doting fool.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Be silent ass.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: With all my heart my Lords, my humble leave my Lords
Gods mother ass and fool for speaking truth,
It is terrible, but fare ye well my Lords.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Nay stay good Falconbridge, impute it rage,
That thus abuses your right reverend age,
My brothers are too hot.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Too hot indeed, fool, ass, for speaking truth? it is, more than need.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Nay good Sir Richard at my kind entreat
For all the love I bear your noble house,
Let not your absence kindle further wrath,
Each side is at counsel now sit down I pray,
I will quite it with the kindest love I may.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Aye to his wife.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Prince Richard I will sit down,
But by the faith I owe fair Englands Crown,
Had you not been I would have left the place,
My service merits not so much disgrace.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Good Falconbridge I thank thee.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: And you will think of him, if you can step into his bower at Stepney.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Prince Richard is very kind, I know his kindness,
He loves me, but he loves my Lady better,
No more, I will watch him, I will prevent his game,
Young Lad, it is, ill to halt before the lame.

div1.stage: They breake a sunder. Papers this while being offred and subscribed betweene eyther.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: I will not subscribe to this indignity,
I will not be called a King but be a King;
Allow me half the Realm, give me the North,
The Provinces that lie beyond the Seas,
Wales and the Isles that compass in the main.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Nay give him all and he will scant be pleased.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Brother you ask too much.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Too much, too little, he shall have that and more, I swear he shall.
I will have Nottingham and Salisbury,
Stafford and Darby, and some other Earldom,
Or by Saint Iohn (whose blessed name I bear)
I will make these places like a wilderness.
Is it not a plague, an horrible abuse,
A King, a King of England should be Father
To four such proper youths, as Hall , and Dicke ,
My brother Geffrey and my proper self,
And yet not give his sons such maintenance,
As he consumes among his minions.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Be more respective Iohn .

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Respective Richard , are you turned pure? a changing weathercock?
I say it is, reason Henry should be King,
Thou Prince, I Duke, as Ieffry is a Duke.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: What shall your Father do?

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Live at his prayers, have a sufficient pension by the year,
Repent his sins because his end is near.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: A gracious son, a very gracious son.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Will this content you? I that have sat still,
Amazed to see my sons devoid of shame;
To hear my subjects with rebellious tongues,
Wound the kind bosom of their Sovereign,
Can no more bear, but from a bleeding heart
Deliver all my love, for all your hate:
Will this content thee cruel Elinor ?
Your savage mother, my uncivil Queen;
The Tigress that hath drunk the purple blood,
Of three times twenty thousand valiant men;
Washing her red chaps, in the weeping tears,
Of widows, virgins, nurses, sucking babes.
And lastly sorted with her damned consorts,
Entered a labyrinth to murther love.
Will this content you? she shall be released,
That she may next seize me she most envies.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Our mothers liberty is some content.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: What else would Henry have?

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: The Kingdom.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Peruse this bill, draw near let us confer.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: Hall be not answered but with Sovereignty,
For glorious is the sway of Majesty.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: What would content you John ?

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: Five Earldoms Sir.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: What you son Richard?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Pardon gracious father, and the furtherance for my vow of penance
For I have sworn to God and all his Saints,
These arms erected in rebellious brawls,
Against my Father and my Sovereign,
Shall fight the battles of the Lord of hosts,
In wronged Iudea and Palestina,
That shall be Richards penance for his pride,
His blood a satisfaction for his sin,
His patrimony men, munition,
And means to waft them into Siria.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Thou shalt have thy desire Heroic Son,
As soon as other home-bred brawls are done.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Why weeps old Falconbridge?

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: I am almost blind, to hear sons cruel, and the fathers kind,
Now well a near that ere I lived to see,
Such patience and so much impiety.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Brother content thee this is but the first,
Worse is a-brewing, and yet not the worst.

sp.speaker: Lei.
sp.l: You shall not stand to this.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: And why my Lord?

sp.speaker: Ley.
sp.l: The lands of Moorton doth belong to Iohn.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: What is that to me, by Act of Parliament,
If they be mine confirmed, he must be pleased.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Be pleased King puppet? have I stood for thee,
Even in the mouth of death? opened my arms
To circle in seditious ugly shape?
Shook hands with duty, bad adieu to virtue,
Profaned all Majesty in heaven and earth;
Writ in black Characters on my white brow,
The name of rebel Iohn against his Father:
For thee, for thee, thou Otimie of honour,
Thou worm of Majesty thou froth, thou bubble.
And must I now be pleased in peace to stand,
While statutes make thee owner of my land?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Good pastime good, now will the thieves fall out?

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: O if I do, let me be never held
Royal King Enures son pardon me father,
Pull down this rebel that hath done thee wrong.
Dicke, come and leave his side, assail him Lords,
Let us have no parley but with bills and swords.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: Peace Iohn, lay down thy arms, hear Henry speak,
He minds thee no such wrong.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: He were not best.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Why harebrained brother can ye brooke no jest?
I do confirm you Earl of Nottingham.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: And Moorton too?

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Aye and Moorton too.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Why so, now once more I will sit down by you.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Blow wind, the youngest of King Henries stock,
Would fitly serve to make a weathercock.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Gape earth, challenge thine own as Gloucester lies,
Pity such muck is covered with the skies.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Be quiet good my Lords, the Kings command
You should be quiet, and it is very meet,
It is most convenient, how say you Prince Richard?

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: It is indeed.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Why that is wisely said, you are a very kind indifferent man,
Marry a God and by my hollidame,
Were not I had a feeling in my head,
Of some suspicion twixt my wife and him,
I should affect him more than all the world.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Take heed old Richard, keep thee there mad lad,
My sister is fair, and beauty may turn bad.

div1.stage: Enter Robert Hood a paper in his hand.

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.l: Room there, make room for young Huntington.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: A gallant youth, a proper Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Richard I have had wrong about his wardship.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: You cannot right yourself.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: He can and shall.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Not with your help but honourable youth
Have ye performed the business I enjoined?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: I have, and Skink is come, here is his bill,

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: No matter for his bill let him come in.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Let him not enter, his infectious breath
Will poison the assembly.

sp.speaker: Gl.
sp.l: Never doubt, there is more infectious breaths about your Throne,
Leyster is there, your envious Sons is there;
If them you can endure, no poison fear.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Content thee Gloucester.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: I must be content, when you that should mend all are patient,

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Welcome good Skink thou justly dost complain,
Thou standst in dread of death for Rosamond,
Whom thou didst poison at our dread command,
And the appointment of our gracious Mother;
See here my Fathers hand unto thy pardon.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: I receive it graciously, wishing his soul sweet peace, in heaven for so meritorious a work, for I fear me I have not his heart though his hand.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Be sure thou haste not, murderous bloodsucker,
To jealous envy executioner.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Besides thou suest to have some maintenance,
We have bethought us how we will reward thee,
Thou shalt have Rowden Lordship.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: Shall he so? will you reward your murtherers with my lands

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Your lands? it is our gift and he shall have it.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: I will give him seizure first with this and this.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: Lay hold on Gloucester .

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Hold that murtherous Skink .

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Villains hands off, I am a Prince, a Peer,
And I have borne disgrace while I can bear.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Knaves leave your rudeness, how now brother
Gloucester? nay be appeased, be patient brother.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Shift for thyself good Skink, there is gold, away:
Here will be parts.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: 'swounds I will make one and stay.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: I prithee be gone since thus it falleth out,
Take water, hence, away, thy life I doubt.

sp.speaker: Ski.
sp.l: Well, farewell, get I once out of door,
Skink never will put trust in warrants more.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Will Gloucester not be bridled?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Yes my Liege and saddled too, and rid, and spurred and reined,
Such misery (in your Reign) falls your friends,
Let go my arms, you dunghills let me speak.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Where is that knave Skink ? I charge you see him stayed.

sp.speaker: Fauk.
sp.l: The swift heeled knave is fled, body-a-me here is rule,
Here is work indeed.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Follow that Skink, let privy search be made,
Let not one pass except he be well known,
Let posts be every way sent speedily,
For ten miles compass round about the City.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Take Gloucester to you Lieutenant of the Tower,
Keep him aside till we confer a while,
Father you must subscribe to his committing.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Why must he Henry ?

sp.speaker: Ley.
sp.l: Marry for this cause, he hath broke peace and violated laws.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: So have you all done, rebels as you be.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Good words good brother, hear me gracious Lords,

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: I prithee Falconbridge be patient,
Gloucester must of force answer this contempt.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: I will not yield he shall unto the Tower,
Warden of the Fleet take you the charge of Gloucester .

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Why be it so, yet stay with him a while,
Till we take order for the company
That shall attend him, and resort to him.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Warden of the Fleet I see I am your charge,
Befriend me thus, least by their command,
I be prevented of what I intend.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: Command me any service in my power.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: I pray you call some nimble footed fellow,
To do a message for me to my sister.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: Call in Redcap , he waiteth with a Tipstaff,
He stammers, but he is, swift and trusty Sir.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: No matter for his stammering, is this he?

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.l: I am Redcap sir.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Run Redcap to Stepney.

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.l: I will be at Stepney presently.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Nay stay, go to the Lady Falconbridge my sister.

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.l: The Lady falconbridge, I run sir.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: But take thy errand, tell her I am prisoner,
Committed to the Fleet.

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.l: I am glad of that, my father the porter sha-shall get a fee by you.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Stand still a while, desire her to make means
Unto Prince Richard for my liberty,
At thy return (make speed) I will reward thee.

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.l: I am gone si-sir.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Commend me to her gentle Huntington,
Tell her in these affairs I will stand her friend,
Her brother shall not long be prisoner:
Say I will visit her immediately.
Be gone sweet boy to Marian Falconbridge,
Thou lookest like love persuade her to be loving.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: So far as honour will I will persuade,
I will lay loves battery to her modest ears,
Second my mild assault, you may chance win,
Fare parley at the least, may hap pass in.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Here take your charge, let no man speak with him,
Except ourself, our brethren, or Earl Leicester.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Not I my Lord, may not I speak with him?

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Yes Falconbridge thou shalt.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: And why? he is his wife's brother.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Earl Iohn, although I be, I am true unto the State, and so is he.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: What, shall I have no servant of my own?

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: No but the household servants of the Fleet.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: I thank you kinsman King, your father knows,
Gloucester may boldly give a base slave blows.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: O but not here, it was not well done here.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Farewell good Gloucester, you shall hear from us.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Even what your Sons will suffer you to send;
Is it not a misery to see you stand,
That some time was, the Monarch of this land,
Entreating traitors for a subjects freedom?

sp.speaker: Lei.
sp.l: Let him not speak, away with him to prison.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Here is like to be a well stayed common wealth,
Where in proud Leister, and licentious Iohn,
Are pillars for the King to lean upon,.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: We will hear your railing Lecture in the Fleet.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: On our displeasure see he speak no more.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: On thy displeasure, well ye have me here;
O that I were within my Fort of Bungye
Whose walls are washed with the clear streams of Aueney
Then would not Gloucester pass a halfpenny,
For all these rebels, and their poor King too.
Laughest thou King Henry? thou knows my words are true,
God help thee good old man, adieu adieu.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: That Castle shall be mine, where stands it Falconbridge

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Far from your reach sure, under Feckhill ridge,
Five hundred men (England hath few such wight)
Keeps it for Gloucester's use both day and night:
But you may easily win it, wantons words
Quickly can master men, tongues out brawl swords.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Ye are an Idiot.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: I prithee Iohn forbear.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: What shall old winter with his frosty jests,
Cross flowery pleasure?

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Aye and nip you too, God marry mother I would tickle you
Were there no more in place but I and you.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Seize these contentions, forward to the Tower,
Release Queen Elinor, and leave me there
Your prisoner I am sure, if ye had power,
There is nothing lets you but the Commons fear:
Keep your State Lords, we will by water go,
Making the fresh Thames, salt with tears of woe.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: And we will by land through the City ride,
Making the people tremble at our pride.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: Blackheath quoth he, and I were King of all Kent,
I would give it for a commodity of Apron-strings, to
Be in my cottage again. Princes warrants, marry Skink
Finds them as sure as an obligation sealed with butter.
At Kings Bridge I durst not enter a boat, through
London the stones were fiery, I have had a good
Cool way through the fields, and in the high way
To Ratcliffe stands a heater: Mile End is covered with
Who goes there. It is for me sure; O Kent, O Kent,
I would give my part of all Christendom to feel
Thee as I see thee. If I go forward I am stayed,
If I go backward there is a rogue in a red cap, he is, run
From Saint Iohnes after me: I were best stay here,
Least if he come with hue and cry, he stop me yonder,
I would slip the collar for fear of the halter;
But here comes my runner, and if he run for me,
His race dies, he is as sure dead, as if a Parliament
Of Devils had decreed it.

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.l: Stepney church yonder, but I have forgot
The Lady Fau-Fau-Fau plague on her,
I must back to the Fleet to know it.
The Lady Falconbridge, plague on it; Gloucester
Will go near to stab me, for forgetting
My errand, he is such a mad Lord, the
Lady Fau-Fau-Fau.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: Help me devise, upon my life this fool is sent
From Gloucester to his sister Marian .

sp.speaker: Redc.
sp.l: I must needs go back, the Lady
Fau-Fau-Fau.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: God speed good fellow.

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.l: God speed you sir.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: Why runnest thou from me?

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.l: Marry sir, I have lost a Lady's name, and I am running back to seek it.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: What Lady? I prithee stay.

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.l: Why the Lady Fau-Fau-Fau.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: Falconbridge?

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.l: I the same, farewell, I thank you heartily

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: If thou wouldst speak with her she is in Kent,
I serve her, what is, thy business with my Lady?

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.l: I should do an errand to her from my Lord
Of Gloucester, but and she be in Kent, I will send it by you.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: Where is my Lord?

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.l: Marry prisoner in the Fleet, and would have her speak to Prince Richard for his release.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: I have much business, hold there is thy fare by water, my Lady lies this night.

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.l: Where I pray?

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: At Grauesend at the Angel.

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.l: It is devilish cold going by water.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: Why there is my cloak and hat to keep thee warm,
Thy cap and Jerkin will serve me to ride in
By the way, thou hast wind and tide, take Oars.
My Lady will reward thee royally.

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.l: God a mercy, faith and ever thou come to the Fleete, I will give the turning of the key for nothing.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: Hie thee, tomorrow morning at Graues-end I will wash thy stammering throat with a mug of ale merrily.

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.l: God be with you till soon; what call you the Lady? O now I remember the Lady Falconbridge at what sign?

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: At the Angel.

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.l: Angel, the Lady Falconbridge, falconbridge.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: Farewell and be hanged good stammering ninny, I think I have set your Redcaps heels a running, wold your Pyanet chattering humour could as safely set me from the searchers walks. Yonder comes some one, hem: Skink to your tricks this tytty, tytty, a the tongue I believe will fail me.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Come make up to this fellow, let the other go, he seems a gentleman, what are you sir?

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: Would I had kept my own suit, if the countenance carry it away.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Stand sirrah, what are you?

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: The po-po-Porters Son of the Fleet, going to Stepney about business to the Lady Falconbridge.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Well bring him thither, some two or three of ye honest neighbours, and so back to the Fleet, we will show ourselves diligent above other Officers.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: Why let me run I am Redcap.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Well, sure you shall now run no faster than I lead you, hear ye neighbour Simmes, I leave my staff with ye, be vigilant I pray you, search the suspicious houses at the town's end, this Skink is a trouncer; come, will you be gone sir?

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: Yes sir, and the devil go with you and them,
Well, yet have hope mad heart, come your way.

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.l: Sweet nobility in reversion, Blocke by the commission of his head, Conjures you and withal binds you, by all the tricks that pages pass in time of Parliament, as swearing to the pantable, crowning with Custards, paper whiffs to the sleepers noses, cutting of tags, stealing of torches, cum multis aliis tell Blocke, what Blocke you have cast in the way of my Ladies content.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Block by the antiquity of your ancestry, I have given your Lady not so much as the least cause of dislike, if she be displeased at any news I bring, it is, more than I must blab.

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.l: Zounds these pages be so proud, they care not for an old Serving-man, you are a ward and so, an Earl, and no more: you disquiet our house that is the most: and I may be even with thee that is the least.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: What Blocke, what Blocke I say what do you there?

sp.speaker: Bloc.
sp.l: Making the young Lord merry Madam,

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Go attend the gate, see if you can let in more grief thereat,

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.l: Zounds and grief come in there, and I see him once I will Conjure his gaberdine.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: will you be gone sir?

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.l: Hem, these women, these women, and she be not in love either with Prince Richard or this lad, let blocks head be made a chopping blocke.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Fair Madam, what reply you to my suit,
The prince excepts smiles, welcomes, loving looks,

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: The Prince, if he give heed to Marrians suit,
Must hear heart-sighs, see sorrow in my eyes,
And find cold welcome to calamities,

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: And why for gods sake?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Even for Gloucester's sake,

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: why by mine honour, and Prince Richards faith,
Your brother Gloucester shall have liberty,
Upon condition you release a prisoner
That you have long held in captivity.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I have no prisoner,

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Yes a world of eyes, your beauty in a willing bondage ties

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Go to, you are disposed to jest my Lord,

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: In earnest I must be an earnest suitor
To you for love, yet you must be my tutor.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Are you in love?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: I dearly love Prince Richard.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Then do you love the loveliest man alive.
The Princeliest person of King Henries sons,

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: I like this well.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: he is virtuous in his mind his body fair,
His deeds are Just, his speeches debonair,

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Better and better still.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: In deed he is what nobody can deny.
All lovely, beauty all, all Majesty.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: I will tell his excellence what you report,
No doubt he will be very thankful, for it,

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Nay hear you young Lord? Gods pity staye.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: What have you more in Richards praise to say?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I have said too much if you misconster me.
Duty bids praise him, not unchastity.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Unchastity holy heavens forfend it,
That he or I, or you should once intend it,

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.l: They are there sir, close at it, I leave you sir, the more Room the less company.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Drink that, farewell,

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.l: If that sir Richard comes, this ties, this binds,
O gold, thy power converts servants minds.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: How now fair Madam who hath angered you?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Grief at my brothers durance angers me.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: I had thought my Ward young Huntington had vexed you

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: who he? alas good Gentleman he wronged me not.
No matter for all this, I will tell your tale.
A noise within, Enter Skink, Blocke, Constable.

sp.speaker: Bls.
sp.l: Sir there comes no more of you in with him than the Constable. Zounds here is a beadroll of Bills at the gate indeed, back ye base

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Now sirrah whats the matter?

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.l: Marry here is a stammerer taken clipping the Kings English, and the Constable and his watch hath brought him to you to be examined.

sp.speaker: Consta.
sp.p: No Madam we, are commanded by the King to watch, and meeting this fellow at Mile-end, he tells us, he is the Porters son of the Fleet, that the Earl of Gloucester sent him to you.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: Aye forsooth he desire you to speak to the Prince for him.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: O I conceive thee, bid him blithely fare,
Bear him this Ring in token of my care.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: If I be rid of this evil Angel that haunts me, many rings, much Fleet will Skink come unto.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Madam, if you know this fellow we will discharge him.

sp.speaker: Bloc.
sp.l: Madam, and you be wise, trust your honest neighbours here, let them bring this ca-ca-ca-ca to the Fleet, and see your ring delivered.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: A plague upon you for a damned rogue,
The Porter of the Fleet will surely know me.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Good neighbours bring this honest fellow thither,
There is for his pains a crown if he say true,
And for your labour there is as much for you.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: Why Madam, I am Redcap the Porters son.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Thou hast no wrong in this, farewell good fellow.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: Best speaking to Prince Richard? no I will try
And face out Redcap if the slave were by.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Make them drink Blocke.

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.l: Come to the Buttery bar, stitty stitty stammerer, come honest Constable, hey the watch of our town, we will drink trylill I faith.

div1.stage: As they goe out, enters Sir Richard Faukenbridge stealing forward, Prince and Lady talking.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Lupus in fabula my Noble Lord,
See the old fox Sir Richard Falconbridge.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: We will fit him well enough, second us Robin.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I will fit you well enough for all your hope,

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Leave quaffing sirrah, listen to their talk.

sp.speaker: Bloc.
sp.p: O while you live beware, two are sooner seen than one: besides, bear a brain Master, if Block should be now spied, my Madam would not trust this sconce neither in time nor tide.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Well leave me, now it buds; see see, they kiss.

sp.speaker: Bloc.
sp.l: Adieu good old sinner, you may recover it with a salad of parsley, and the herb patience, if not sir you know the worst, it is, but even this.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Madam, what you desire I not deny,
But promise Gloucester's life and liberty,
I beg but love.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: When doth she give her alms?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Fair honourable Prince.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Nay then they speed.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: My soul hath your deserts in good esteem.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Witness these goodly times that grace my head

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: But were you the sole Monarch of the earth,
Your power were insufficient to invade,
My never yielding heart of chastity.

sp.speaker: Fauk.
sp.l: Sayst thou so Mall, I promise thee for this,
I will owe thy cherry lips an old man's kiss;
Look how my Cockerel droops, it is no matter,
I like it best when women will not flatter.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Nay but sweet Lady.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Nay but gracious Lord, do not so much forget your Princely worth,
As to attempt virtue to unchastity.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: O noble youth!

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Let not the Lady's dead grief for her brother,
Give life to shameless and detested sin.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Sweet child.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Consider that she is of high decent.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Most virtuous Earl.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Wife to the noblest Knight that ever breathed.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Now blessing on thee blessed Huntington.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: And would you then first stain your Princely stock,
Wrong beauty, virtue, honour, chastity,
And blemish Falconbridge's untainted arms?

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: By adding horns unto our Falcon's head,
Well thought on noble youth, it was well put in.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Besides my gracious Lord.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Tickle him Mall, plague him on that side for his hot desire.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: however secretly great Princes sin,

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: O now the spring she will do it secretly.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: The King of all hearts will have all sins known.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Ah then she yields not.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Lady here is my hand, I did but try your honourable faith

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: He did but try her, would she have been tried
It had grown hard on this and on this side.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: And since I see your virtue so confirmed,
as vice can have no entrance in your heart,
I vow in sight of heaven never again,
To move like question but for love,

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: My heart is eased, hold Blocke take up my cloak.

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.l: And your cap too sir.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Sir Richard?

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: What sweet Prince welcome yfaith,
I see youth quickly gets the start of age;
But welcome welcome and young Huntington.
Sweet Robyn hood, honour's best flowering bloom,
Welcome to Falconbridge with all my heart,
How cheers my love, how fares my Marrian, ha?
Be merry chuck, and Prince Richard welcome,
Let it go Mall I know thy grievances.
Away away, tut let it pass sweet girl,
We needs must have his help about the Earl.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Let it not be delayed dear Falconbridge.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Sir Richard, first make suit unto my father,
I will follow you to Court and second you,

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Follow to Court, ha? then I smell a rat,
It is probable he will have about again,
Long siege makes entrance to the strongest fort,
It must not be I must not leave him here,
Prince Richard, if you love my brothers good,
Let us ride back to the Court, I will wait on you,

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: He is, Jealous, but I must observe the time,
We will ride unto the Court, I will leave my boy
Till we return, are you agreed to this?

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: O Aye he is an honourable youth.
Virtuous and modest, Huntington's right heir,
His father Gilbert was the smoothest faced Lord
That ever bare Arms in England or in France,

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Solicit Robin, Lady give good ear,
And of your brothers freedom never fear,

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Marrian farewell, wheres Blocke? open the gate,
Come Prince God send us to prove fortunate?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: why do you stay sir?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Madam as a Lieger to solicit for your absent love

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Walk in the Garden I will follow you.
I'faith I'faith you are a noble wag.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: An honourable wag, and waggish Earl.
Even what you will sweet Lady I must bear,
Hoping of patience, profit will ensue.
That you will bear the Prince as I bear you.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Well said well said, I will have these toys amended,
Go, will you walk into the Garden sir,

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: But will you promise me to bring no maids,
To set upon my little manship there?
You threatened whipping, and I am in fear,

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Upon my word I will bring none but myself,

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: You see I am weaponed, do not I beseech you,
I will stab them come there twenty ere they breech me.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: This youth and Richard, think me easily won,
But Marrian rather will embrace,
The bony carcass of dismaying death,
Than prove unchaste to Noble Falconbridge,
Richard is king Henries son, is light,
Wanton and loves not humble modesty,
Which makes me (much contrary to my thoughts)
Flatter his humour for my brothers safety,
But I protest I will dwell among the dead,
Ere I pollute my sacred nuptial bed.

div1.stage: Enter Gloster in his gowne, calling

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Porter what Porter where is this drowsy ass?

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Who calls? my Lord of Gloucester all alone?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Alone and have your wisdom's company,
Pray where is the stammering chatterer your son?
He is, ever running but he makes small haste,
I will bring his lither legs in better frame,
And if he serve me thus another time.
Hark sir your clients knock, and it be your pie,
Let him vouchsafe to chatter us some news,
Tell him we dance attendance in our chamber.
This Iohn and Henry are so full of hate,
That they will have my head by some device,
Gloucester hath plotted means for an escape,
And if it fadge, why so; if not, then well,
The way to heaven is death, this life is a hell.

sp.speaker: Port.
sp.l: Why should the Watchmen come along with thee?

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.p: There is such a question for yon same rogue Skink plague keep far enough from him, that an honest fellow cannot walk the streets.

sp.speaker: Port.
sp.l: Well sir dispatch your business with the Earl,
He is, angry at your stay I tell ye that.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: Sbloud what a frown this Gloucester casts at me,
I hope he means to lend me no more cuffs,
Such as he paid me at the Parliament.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: What mutter you, what tidings from my sister?

sp.speaker: Ski.
sp.l: Commendations and she hath sent ye this ring.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Hold there is two Angels, shut the chamber door,
You must about some business for me straight;
Come nearer man,

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: I fear I am too near,

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Hast thou no tidings for my liberty?

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: No but ye shall he hear from her presently.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: And presently sir off with your coat.
Nay quick, uncase, I am bold to borrow it,
I will leave my gown, change is no robbery.
Stutterer it is, so, never flinch, ye cannot pass,
Cry, and by heaven I will cut thy cowards throat,
Quickly cashier yourself, you see me staye,

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: Nay, but what mean ye?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: To scape I hope, sir with your privilege,
How now, who is this, my fine familiar Skink?
Queen Beldam's minion,

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: Zounds you see it is I.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Time sorts not now to know these mysteries.
How thou camest by this ring, or stolest this coat,
They are mine now in possession, for which kindness
If I escape I will get thee Liberty,
Or fire the fleet about the Wardens ears,
Mum budget not a word as thou lovest thy life,

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: I mum mum fair, pray God may chance it,
My Lord, but that my state is desperate,
I would see your eyes out ere I would be cheated.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Walk like an Earl villain some are coming.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Where is this Gloucester?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: yonder he walks. father, I let me out.

sp.speaker: Port.
sp.l: Why whether must you now?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: To Jericho I think, it is such a humorous Earl.

sp.speaker: Port.
sp.l: Well sir wilt please you hasten home again.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: I I will be here in a trice; but pray have care of this madcap, if he give us the slip, some of us are like to make a slippery occupation on it.

div1.stage: This while John walkes and stalke by Skinke, neuer a word betwene them.

sp.speaker: Port.
sp.l: Look to your business sir let me alone.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Alone? never trust me if I trouble thee.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Mad Gloucester mute, all mirth turned to despair?
Why now you see what it is to cross a King,
Deal against Princes of the Royal blood,
You will snarl and rail, but now your tongue is be-dried,
Come caper hay, set all at six and seven,
What musest thou with thought of hell or heaven?

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: Of neither Iohn I muse at my disgrace,
That I am thus kept prisoner in this place.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: O sir, a number are here prisoners,
My Cousin Moorton whom I came to visit,
But he good man is at his morrow mass,
But I that neither care to say nor sing,
Come to seek that preaching hate and prayer,
And while they mumble up their Orisons,
We will play a game at bowls, what sayst thou Gloucester?

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: I care not if I do,

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: You do not care, Let old men care for graves, we for our sports,
Off with your gown, there lies my hat and Cloak,
The bowls there quickly, he?

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: No my gown stirs not, it keeps sorrow warm,
And she, and I am not to be divorced,

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Yes there is an axe must part your head and you,
And with your head, sorrow will leave your heart.
But come shall I begin? a pound a game,

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: More pounds and we thus heavy? well begin.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Rub rub rub rub.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: A men God send it short enough, and me
A safe running with them clothes from thee.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Play Robin run run run.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: Far enough and well, fly one foot more,
Would I were half so far without the door.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Now Porter whats the news?

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Your Cousin Moorton humbly craves,
Leaving your game, you would come visit him,

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Bowl Gloucester I will come presently.
So near mad Robin? then have after you,

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: Would I were gone, make alter as you may,

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Well sir it is yours, one all, throw but the Iacke
While I go talk with Moorton: I will not stay,
Keep Cloak and hat in pawn I will hold out play,

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: I would be sorry Iohn but you should stay,
Until my bias run another way,
Now pass, and hey pass, Skink unto your tricks,
It is but a chance at hazard: there lies Gloucester,
and here stands Skink, now Iohn play thou thy part,
And if I scape I will love thee with my heart.
So porter let me forth.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: God bless your grace, ye spoke with the Lady Moorton

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: I have and must about his business to the Court.
It grieves me to break my sport with Gloucester,
The melancholy Earl is comfortless,

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: I wold your grace would comfort him from hence,
The Fleet is weary of his company,

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: Drink that, some knocks, I prithee let me out.
His head shall off ere long, never make doubt.

div1.stage: Enter Iohn at the other doore.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Now madcap thou winnest all, where art thou Robyn?
Uncased: nay then he means to play in earnest.
But where is my Cloak, my rapier, and my hat?
I hold my birth-right to a beggars scrip,
The bastard is escaped in my clothes.
It is well, he left me his to walk the streets,
I will fire the City but I will find him out,
Perchance he hides himself to try my spleen,
I will to his chamber, Gloucester? hallo Gloucester?

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: I wonder how thou camest so strangely changed?
It is not an hour since thou wentest from hence,

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.p: By my Christendom I have not been here this three nights, a plague of him, that made me such a chanting and sent me such a jaunt, blood I was stayed for Skink, that ill faced rogue.

sp.speaker: Port.
sp.l: I pray God there be no practise in this change.
Now I remember these are Skink's clothes,
That he wore last day, at the Parliament,

div1.stage: Knocke, Enter at another doore, John in Glosters gowne.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Porter? you Porter?

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Do you not hear them knock, you must stay sir,

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Blood I could eat these rogues.

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.l: What raw, it is a very harsh morsel,
Next your heart

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: A plague upon your Jaunts, what porter slave?

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.l: I have been at g-grauesend sir.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: What is that to me?

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.l: And at Canterbury.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: And at the gallows: zounds this frets my soul.

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.l: But I could not find your sister the Lady falconbridge.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: You stammering slave hence, chat among your Daws,
Come ye to mad me? while the rogue your father.

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.l: My father.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Porter? you damned slave.

sp.speaker: Port.
sp.l: Is it Midsummer do you begin to rave?

sp.speaker: Iob.
sp.l: Hark how the traitor flouts me to my teeth.
I would entreat your knaveship let me forth,
For fear I dash your brains out with the keys,
What is become of Gloucester and my garments?

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Alas in your apparel Gloucester is gone,
I let him out, even now I am undone,

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: It was your practise, and to keep me back
You sent Iacke Daw your son with ca-ca-ca,
To tell a sleeveless tale: lay hold on him,
To Newgate with him and you tut acute,
Run redcap and trudge about,
Or bid your fathers portership farewell.

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.p: Here is a good Jest by the Lord to mock an ape with all: my father has brought his Hoges to a fair market. Po-po-porter quoth you? porter that will for me, and I po-po-porter it, let them po-po-post me to heaven in this quarter. But I must seek this. Gloucester and Skink that cony-catching rascal, a plague confound him, Redcap must run he cannot tell whither.

div1.stage: Sound Trumpets, Enter Henry the younger, on one hand of him Queene Elinor, on the other Leycester.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Mother and Leycester add not oil to fire,
Wrath is kindled with a word, and cannot hear
The number less persuasions you infort,

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: O but my son thy father favours him.
Richard that vile abortive changeling brat,
And Falconbridge, are fallen at Henries feet.
They woo for him, but entreat my son
Gloucester may die for this that he hath done,

sp.speaker: Leic.
sp.l: If Gloucester hue thou wilt be overthrown,

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: If Gloucester live thy mother dies in moan,

sp.speaker: Ley.
sp.l: If Gloucester live Lester will fly the realm,

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: If Gloucester live thy kingdom is but a dream,

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Have I not sworn by that eternal arm
That puts just vengeance sword in Monarch's hands,
Gloucester shall die for his presumption?
What needs more conjuration gracious Mother?
And honourable Lester mark my words.
I have a Beadroll of some threescore Lords,
Of Gloucester's faction,

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Nay of Henries faction.
Of thy false fathers faction, speak the truth,
He is the head of factions; were he down:
Peace, plenty, glory will impale thy crown.

sp.speaker: Ley.
sp.l: I there is the butt; whose heart-white if we hit,
The game is ours. Well we may rage and rove,
At Gloucester, Lancaster, Chester, Falconbridge,
But he is the upshot.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Yet begin with Gloucester.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: The destinies run to the book of Fates,
And read in never-changing Characters
Robert of Gloucester's end he dies today,
So fate, so heaven, so doth King Henry say.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Imperially resold.

sp.speaker: Leic.
sp.l: The old King comes,

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Then comes Luxurious lust,
The King of Concubines, the King that scorns
The undefiled, chaste and nuptial bed,
The King that hath his Queen Imprisoned.
For my sake scorn him, son call him not father,
Give him the style of a competitor,

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Pride seize upon my heart, wrath fill mine eyes,
Sit lawful majesty upon my front
Duty fly from me, pity be exiled,
Senses forget that I am Henries child,

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: I kiss thee, and I bless thee, for this thought.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: O Lancaster bid Henry yield some reason
Why he desires so much the death of Gloucester,

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: I hear thee Henry, and I thus reply.
I do desire the death of Bastard Gloucester,
For that he spends the Treasure of the Crown.
I do desire the death of bastard Gloucester,
For that he doth desire to pull me down.
Or were this false (I purpose to be plain)
He loves thee, and for that I him disdain.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Therein thou showest a hate corrupted mind,
To him the more unjust, to me unkind.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: He loves you as his father loved his mother.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Fie, fie upon thee hateful Elinor.
I thought thou hadst been long since scarlet dyed,

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: She is and therefore cannot change her colour.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: You are too strict, Earl Gloucester's fault
Merits not death,

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: By th'rood the Prince says true.
Here is a statute from the Confessor,

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: The Confessor was but a simple fool.
Away with books my word shall be a law,
England her breath shall from this bosom draw,
Gloucester shall die,

sp.speaker: Ley.
sp.l: Let Gloucester die the death.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Lester he shall not, he shall have law, despite of him and thee.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: What law, will you be Traitors? whats the law?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: His right hands loss, and that is such a loss,
As England may lament, all Christians weep.
That hand hath been advanced against the Moors,
Driven out the Sarasins from Gads and Cicile,
Fought fifteen Battles under Christs red cross,
And is it not (think you) a grievous loss,
That for a slave (and for no other harm)
It should be sundered from his Princely Arm?

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: More for example Noble Lancaster, but it is great pity,
Too too great a pity.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: I will have his hand and head.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Thou shalt have mine then.

sp.speaker: Que.
sp.l: Well said stubborn Dicke, Iack wold not serve me so,
Were the boy here:

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Both Iohn and I have served your will too long;
Mother repent your cruelty and wrong:
Gloucester you know is full of mirth and glee,
And never else did your grace injury.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Gloucester shall die.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: Fetch him here I will see him dead.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: He that stirs for him shall lay down his head.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: O quiet good my Lords, patience I pray,
I think he comes unsent for by my fay.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: What meanest thou Gloucester?

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: Who brought Gloucester hither?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Let Gloucester hang and them that
There lies his case, a mischief on his carcass.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: My dear son Iacke?

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Your dear son Iack an apes, your monkey, your baboon, your ass, your gull.

sp.speaker: Ley.
sp.l: What ails Earl Iohn?

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Hence further fro my sight,
My fiery thoughts and wrath have work in hand;
I will curse ye blacker than the Leuarnian Lake,
If you stand wondering at my sorrow thus;
I am with child, big, hugely swollen with rage,
Who will play the Midwife, and my throbs assuage?

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: I will my Son.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: I will high hearted brother.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: You will, and you, tut, tut all you are nothing,
It will out, it will out, myself myself can ease:
You chafe, you swell, ye are commanding King,
My father is your footstool when he please,
Your word is a law, these Lords dare never speak,
Gloucester must die, your enemies must fall.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: What means our brother?

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: He means that thou art mad she frantic, Lester foolish
I the babe, these grind us, bite us, vex us, charge,
And discharge, Gloucester, O Gloucester!

sp.speaker: Que.
sp.l: Where is Gloucester son?

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Where is Gloucester. brother?

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: I hope he be escaped.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: O I could tear my hair, and falling thus upon the
Solid earth, dig into Gloucester's grave, so he were dead
And gone into the depth of under worlds.
Or get seditious hundred thousand hands,
And like Briareus, battle with the Stars,
To pull him down from heaven if he were there.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Look to Earl Iohn the Gentleman is mad.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: O who would not be mad at this disgrace?
Gloucester the fox is fled, there lies his case,
He cozened me of mine, the porter helped him,

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: The porter shall be hanged let us part and seek him,
Gloucester shall die all Europe shall not save him.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: He is wise, too wise for us, yet I will go with you,
To get more fools into my company.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: This is your fathers plot, revenge it son.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Father by heaven if this were your advice,
Your head or heart shall pay the bitter price,
Come mother, Brother, Lester, let us away,

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Aye, I will be one, in hope to meet the bastard,
And then no more myself will be his headsman.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Richard and Falconbridge follow the search,
You may prevent mischance by meeting Gloucester,
If ye find Skink see that you apprehend him,
I hear there is a wizard at Blackheath,
Let some enquire of him where Skink remains,
Although I trust not to those fallacies,
Yet now and then such men prove Soothsayers.
Will you be gone?

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Withal my heart, withal my heart my Lord,
Come Princely Richard, we are ever yoked.
Pray God there be no mystery in this,

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Be not suspicious where there is no cause,

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Nay nothing, nothing, I am but in jest.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Call in a Pursuivant.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Here is one my Liege,

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: There is a Porter likely to be hanged,
For letting Gloucester scape, sirrah attend,
You shall have a reprieve to bring him us,
These boys are too too stubborn Lancaster,
But it is their mothers fault, if thus she move me,
I will have her head though all the world reprove me.

div1.stage: Enter Robin Hood and Lady Faukenbridge.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Do not deny me gentle Huntington.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: My Lord will miss me.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Tut let me excuse thee.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Turn woman, O it is intolerable!
Except you promise me to play the Page:
Do that, try one night, and you will, laugh forever,
To hear the Orisons that Lovers use;
Their ceremonious sighs, their idle oaths,
To hear how you are praised and prayed unto.
For you are Richards Saint, they talk of Marry
The blessed Virgin, but upon his beads
He only prays to Marian Falconbridge.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: The more his error, but will you agree
To be the Lady Falconbridge one day?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: When is it?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: On Monday.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Wherefore is it?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Nay then you do me wrong with inquisition.
And yet I care not greatly if I tell thee.
Thou seest my husband full of jealousy;
Prince Richard in his suit importunate,
My brother Gloucester threatened by young Henry;
To clear these doubts, I will in some disguise,
Go to Blackheath unto the holy Hermit,
Whose wisdom in fore-telling things to come,
Will let me see the issue of my cares.
If destinies ordain me happiness,
I will chase these mists of sorrow from my heart,
With the bright Sun of mirth: if fate agree,
It, and my friends, must suffer misery,
Yet I will be merry too, till mischief come.
only I long to know the worst of all.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: I will once put on a scarlet countenance.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Be wary least ye be discovered Robyn.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Best paint me then, be sure I shall not blush.

div1.stage: Enter Block bleeding, Gloster with him.

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.l: Beat an Officer, Redcap I will have ye talked withal,
Beat Sir Richards Porter? help Madam, help,

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Peace you damned rogue.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Brother I pray you forbear.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Zwonds a hundredth at my heels almost,
And yet the villain stands on compliment.

sp.speaker: Bloc.
sp.l: A bots one you, is it you?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Will you to the door you fool? and bar the gate,
Hold there is an angel for your broken pate;
If any knock let them not in in haste.

sp.speaker: Bloc.
sp.l: Well I will do as I see cause, blood thou art dear to me, but here is a sovereign plaster for the sore: gold healeth wounds, gold easeth hearts: what can a man have more?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Dear brother, tell us how you made escape?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: You see I am here, but if you would know how:
I cannot scape and tell the manner too,
By this I know your house is compassed
With hell-hound search.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Brother I will furnish you with beard and hair, and
Garments like my husband, how like you that?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Well, when I have them: quickly then dispatch: sblood turn gray beard and hair?
Robyn conceal, this dieteth my mind,
Mirth is the object of my humorous spleen,
Thou high commanding fury! further device,
Jests are conceited, I long to see their birth,
What come ye sister? Robyn a thieves hand,
But prithee where hadst thou this beard and hair?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Prince Richard wore them hither in a mask,

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Sayst thou me so, faith love the Princely youth,
Tut you must taste stolen pleasure now and than,

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: But if she steal and Jealous eyes espy:
She will be sure condemned of Burglary,

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Ha crake? can your low stumps venture so deep
Into affections stream? go to you wanton.
What want we now? my nightcap, O it is here,
So now no Gloucester, but old Falconbridge,
Hark, the search knocks, I will, let them in myself;
Welcome good fellow; ha, what is it you lack?

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.l: Master Constable, search you that way, and you ho-honest man that way. I will run this way my own self.
Gloucester.
What search you for? what is it you would have?

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.l: Madam, what shall I do to these browne-bill fellows? some run into the wine seller, some here, some there.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Let them alone, let them search their fills.

sp.speaker: Block.
sp.l: I will look to their fingers for all that.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Do so good Blocke, be careful honest Blocke.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.l: Sir stammerer and your watch, you are past i'faith.

sp.speaker: Gl.
sp.l: Will you not speak knaves, tell me who you seek?

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.p: Marry sir we seek a vagabond, a fugitive. my Lady's own brother; but and he were the po-po-Popes own brother, I would search for him; for I have a poor father ready to be hanged for him.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: O it is for Gloucester! marry search a'god's-name,
Seek peace, will he break prison too?
It is pity he should live, nay I defy him.
Come look about, search every little corner,
My self will lead the way, pray you come,
Seek, seek, and spare not, though it be labour lost:
He comes not under my roof, hear ye wife,
He comes not hither, take it for a warning.

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.p: You speak like an honest Gentleman, rest you merry, come my friends, I believe he ran by the garden wall toward the water side.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: This fellow is of the humour I would choose my wife,
Few words and many paces, a word and a way, and so
Must I: Sister adieu, pray you for me, I will do the like for you,
Robin farewell, commend me to the Prince.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Can ye not stay here safe?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: No, I will not trust the changing humours of old Falconbridge,
Adieu young Earl, Sister let us kiss and part;
Tush, never mourn, I have a merry heart.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Farewell all comfort.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: What weeping Lady?
Then I perceive you have forgot Blacke-heath.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: No, there I will learn both of his life and death.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Till Monday Madam I must take my leave.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: You will not miss then:

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Nay, if Robin fail ye, let him have never favour of fair Lady.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Meanwhile I will spend my time in prayers and tears,
That Gloucester may escape these threatened fears.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: Thus jets my noble Skink along the streets,
To whom each bonnet veils, and all knees bend;
And yet my noble humour is too light,
By the six shillings. here are two cracked groats
To helter skelter, at some vaunting house.
But who comes yonder? ha, old Falconbridge?
Hath a brave chain, were Iohn and he good friends,
That chain were mine, and should unto Black-heath.
I will venture, it is, but trial, luck may fall.
Good morrow good sir Richard Falconbridge.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Good morrow my sweet Prince, hearty good morrow,
This greeting well becomes us, marry does it;
Better iwis than strife and jangling.
Now can I love ye, will, ye to the Sheriffs?
Your brother Richard hath been there this hour.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: Yes I am plodding forward as you do;
What cost your chain? it is, passing strongly wrought,
I would my Goldsmith had a pattern of it.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: It is at your graces service, show it him.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: Then dare ye trust me?

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Who the Princely Iohn?
My Sovereigns son, why what a question is that?
I will leave you, ye may know I dare trust you.

sp.speaker: Ski.
sp.l: I will bring it ye to the Sheriff's, excuse my absence.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: I will, my noble Lord, adieu sweet Prince.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: Why so, this breakfast was well fed upon,,
When Skink's devices on Blackheath do fail,
This and such cheats, would set me under sail,
I will to the water side, would it were later,
For still I am afraid to meet Prince Iohn.
But what a mischief meant Falconbridge
To come again so soon? that way he went,
And now comes peaking; upon my life
The buzzard hath me in suspicion,
But whatsoever chance, I will filch a share.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Yonder is Prince Iohn I hope he cannot know me,
There is naught but Gloucester Gloucester in their mouths;
I am half strangled with the Garlic breath,
Of rascals that exclaims as I pass by,
Gloucester is fled, once taken he must die.
But I will to Iohn, how does my gracious Lord?
What tattles rumour now? what news of Gloucester?

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: What news could I hear since you left me last?
Were you not here even now? lent me your chain,
I think you dote.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Sweet Prince, age, age forgets, my brothers chain? a pretty accident,
I will have it and be but in the spite of Iohn.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: There is, more, and more, I will geld it ere it go.
This same shall keep me in some tavern merry,
Till nights black hand curtain this too clear sky.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: My sweet Prince, I have some cause to use my chain,
Another time (when ever your Lordship please)
It is at your service, O marry God it is.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: Here palsy, take your chain, stoop and be hanged,
Yet the fish nibbled, when she might not swallow;
Gout I have curtailed what I could not borrow.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: He is, gone away in frets, would he might meet
My brother Falconbridge in this mad mood,
There would be rare ado; Why this fits me,
My brain flows with fresh wit and policy.
But Gloucester look about, who have we yonder?
Another Iohn Prince, Richard and the Sheriff?
Upon my life, the slave that had the chain,
Was Skink, escaped the Fleet by some mad sleight,
Well, farewell he, better and better still,
These seek for me, yet I will, have my will.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Sheriff, in any case be diligent.
Who is yonder, Falconbridge?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: How now sweet chuck, how fares my lovely Prince?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: What carest thou? or well, or ill, we crave no help of thee.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Gods mother do you scorn me?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Gout, what then?

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Fie, leave these idle brawls, I prithee Iohn
Let us follow that we are enjoined unto.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Aye marry Prince, if now you slip the time,
Gloucester will, slip away; tut though he hate me
I have done service, I have found him out.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: A shame confound thee for thy treachery,
Inconstant dotard, timorous old ass,
That shakes with cowardice not with years.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Go, I have found him, I have winded him.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: O let me hug thee gentle Falconbridge,
Forgive my oft ill using of thine age,
I will call thee Father, I will be penitent,
Bring me where Gloucester is I will be thy slave,
All that is mine, thou in reward shalt have.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Soft, not too hasty, I would not be seen in it,
Marry a god my wife would chide me dead,
If Gloucester by my means should lose his head.
Princely Richard at this corner make your stand:
And for I know you love my sister well,
Know I am Gloucester and not Falconbridge.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Heaven prosper thee sweet Prince in thy escape.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Sheriff, make this your quarter, make good guard.
Iohn, stay you here, this way he means to turn,
By Thomas I lack a sword, body a me.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: What wouldst thou with a sword old Falconbridge?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: O sir to make show in his defence,
For I have left him yonder at a house
A friends of mine, an honest Citizen.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: We will, fetch him thence.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Nay then you injure me, stay till he come; he is in a russet cloak
And must attend me like a Serving-man.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Hold there is my sword, and with my sword my heart,
Bring him for Godsake, and for thy desert,
My brother King and mother Queen shall love thee.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Mark me good Prince, yonder away we come,
I go afore and Gloucester follows me;
Let not the Sheriff nor Richard meddle with us,
Begin you first, seize Gloucester and arrest him;
I will draw and lay about me here and here,
Be heedful that your watchmen hurt me not,

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: I will hang him that doth hurt thee, prithee away,
I love thee, but thou killest me with delay.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Well keep close watch, I will, bring him presently.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Away then quickly.

sp.speaker: Gl.
sp.l: Gloucester, close master Sheriff, Prince Richard,

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Gloucester adieu.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: I trust you.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: By my Knight-hood I will prove true.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Revenge, I will build a Temple to your name;
And the first offering shall be Gloucester's head,
Thy Alters shall be sprinkled with the blood,
Whose wanton current his mad humour fed;
He was a rhymer and a Riddler,
A scoffer at my mother, praised my father,
I will fit him now for; all, escape and all.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Take heed spite burst not in his proper gall.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: How now, what way took Falconbridge I wonder?
That is not Gloucester sure that attends on him.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: He came not at the Sheriff's by the morrow mass,
I sought the Goldsmiths' rowe and found him not;
Sirrah, you are sure he sent not home my chain?

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.l: Who should send your chain sir?

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: The Prince, Prince Iohn I lent it him today.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: What is this they talk?

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.p: By my truth Sir, and ye lent it him, I think you may go look it: for one of the Drawers of the Salutation told me even now, that he had took up a chamber there till evening, and then he will away to Kent.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Body of me, he means to spend my chain,
Come Blocke I will to him.

sp.speaker: Iob.
sp.l: Hear you Falconbridge?

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Why what a knave art thou? yonder is Prince Iohn.

sp.speaker: Bl.
sp.l: Then the Drawer is a knave, he told me Prince Iohn was at the Salutation.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Where is Gloucester Falconbridge?

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Sweet Prince I know not.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: Come, jest not with me, tell me where he is?

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: I never saw him since the Parliament.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Impudent liar, didst thou no: even now
Say thou wouldst fetch him? hadst thou not my sword?

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Wert thou a King, I will not bear the lie,
Thy sword? no boy, thou seest this sword is mine.

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.l: My Master a liar? Zounds wert thou a potentate,

sp.speaker: Fau,
sp.l: I scorn to wear thy arms untutored child,
I fetch thee Gloucester? shameless did I see thee
Since as I went this morning to the Sheriff's,
Thou borrowedst my gold chain?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Thy chain?

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: I hope thou wilt not cheat me princocks Iohn.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: I will cheat thee of thy life if thou charge me
With any chain.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Come, let him come I pray, I will whip ye boy, I will teach you to out-face.

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.l: Come, come, come, but one at once, ye dastards come

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Keep the Kings peace, I see you are both deceived,
He that was lost here, was not Falconbridge.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: They slander me, who says that I was here?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: We, do believe ye sir; nor do you think
My brother Iohn deceived you of a chain.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: He did, I did deliver it with this hand.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: I will die upon the slanderer,

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Let the boy come.

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.l: Aye, let him come, let him come.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Fellow, thou spokest even now, as if prince Iohn
Had been at some old Tavern in the town.

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.l: I sir, I came up now, but from the Salutation,
And a drawer that doth not use to lie, told me
Prince Iohn hath bin there all this afternoon.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: The Devil in my likeness then is there.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: The Devil in thy likeness or thyself,
Had my gold chain.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Thou art the Devil, for thou
Hadst my good sword, all these can witness it.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Gods Mother thou beliest me.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Give me the lie?

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Nay calm this fury, let us down to the Tavern,
Or one, or both, these counterfeits are there.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: I know him well enough that had my chain,
And there be two Iohns, if I find one there,
ByrLady, I will lay him fast.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: It is this Skink that mocks us I believe.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: Alas poor Skink it is the Devil Gloucester;
Who if I be so happy once to find,
I will give contentment, to his troubled mind.

sp.speaker: Rcih.
sp.l: I hope he is, far enough, and free enough:
Yet these conceits I know delight his soul.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Follow me Blocke, follow me honest Blocke.

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.l: Much follow you, I have another piece of work in hand; I hear say Redcaps father shall be hanged this afternoon,, I will see him slip a string though I give my service the slip; beside my Lady bad me hear his examination at his death: I will get a good place, and pen it word for word, and as I like it, set out a mournful Ditty to the tune of Labandalashot, or rowe well ye Mariners, or somewhat as my muse shall me invoke.

div1.stage: Enter Gloster like Faukenbridge with a Purseuant, Gloster hauing a paper in his hand, the Purseuant bare.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: A charitable deed, God bless the King,
He shall be then reprieved.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.l: Aye sir, some day or two, till the young King and Prince
Iohn change it, especially if the good Earl be not found which God forbid.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: What house is this that we, are stepped into to read this warrant in?

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.l: A Tavern sir, the Salutation.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: A Tavern? then I will turn prodigal,
Call for a pint of Sack good fellow.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.l: Drawer?

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.l: Anon sir.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: A pint of thy best Sack my pretty youth.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.l: God bless your worship sir, ye shall have the best in London sir.

sp.speaker: Gl.
sp.l: What knowest thou me? knowest thou old Falconbridge?
I am no Tavern hunter I can tell thee.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: But my Master hath taken many a fair pound of your man Blocke; he was here today sir, and filled two bottles of nippitate sack.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Well, fill us of your nippitate sir.
This is well chanced, but hear ye boy?
Bring Sugar in white paper, not in brown;
For in white paper I have here a trick,
Shall make the Pursuivant first swoon, then sick.
Thou honest fellow what is, thy name?

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.l: My name is Winterborne sir.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: What countryman I prithee?

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.l: Barkeshire and please ye.

sp.speaker: Gl.
sp.l: How long hast thou been sworn a messenger?

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.l: But yesterday and please your worship,
This is the First employment I have had.

div1.stage: Enter Drawer with wine and Suger.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: A good beginning, here have too thee fellow;
Thou art my fellow now thou servest the King,
Nay take Sugar too, Gods Lady dear,
I put it in my pocket, but it is, here:
Drink a good draught I prithee Winterborne.

div1.stage: He drinkes and falles ouer the stoole.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.l: O Lord Sir Richard, the man, the man.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: What a forgetful beast am I? peace boy,
It is his fashion ever when he drinks.
Fellow he hath the falling sickness,
Run fetch two cushions to raise up his head,
And bring a little Key to ope his teeth.
Pursuivant, your warrant and your box,
These must with me, the shape of Falconbridge
Will hold no longer water here about.
Gloucester will, be a proteus every hour,
That Elinor and Lester, Henry, Iohn,
And all that rabble of hate loving curs,
May minister me more mirth to play upon,.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.l: Here is a key sir, and one of our folk to help.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: No matter for a key, help him but in,
And lay him by the fire a little while,
He will, wake immediately, but be heartsick,
There is, money for a candle and thy wine,
I will go but up unto your Alderman's,
And come down presently to comfort him.
Drawer? what Drawer? with a vengeance Drawer.
Speak in the Crown there.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: They be come, the devil crown ye one by one,
Skink thou art betrayed, that master Falconbridge
Missing some of his chain, hath got thee dogged.
Drawer? what Drawer?

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.l: Anon, anon sir.

sp.speaker: Ski.
sp.l: Was not sir Richard Falconbridge below?

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.l: Yes and please ye.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: It does not please me well, knows he that I am here?

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.l: No I protest.

sp.speaker: Ski.
sp.l: Come hither sirrah, I have little money,
But there is some few links of a chain of gold:
Upon your honesty knows not sir Richard,
That I am here?

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.l: No by my holydam.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: Who is that was with him?

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.l: Why a Pursuivant.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: Where is sir Richard?

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.l: At the Alderman's.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: A Pursuivant and at the Alderman's.
What Pig, or Goose, or Capon have you killed,
Withing your Kitchen new?

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.l: A pig new sticked.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: Fetch me a saucer of the blood, quick run;
I will fit the Pursuivant, and Alderman,
And Falconbridge, if Skink have any wit.
Well Gloucester, I did never love thee yet,
But thou art, the maddest Lord that ever I met,
If I scape this, and meet thee once again,
Curse Skink, if he die penny in thy debt.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.l: O my Lord the house is full of halberds, and a great many Gentlemen ask for the room where Prince Iohn is?

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: Lend me thy Apron, run and fetch a pot from the next room,
Betrayed, 'swounds betrayed, by gout, by palsy, by dropsy;
O brave boy, excellent blood: up, take my cloak
And my hat to thy share, when I come from Kent, I will, pay
Thee like a King.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.l: I thank you my Lord.
