div1.stage: Enter John, Richard, Faukenbridge, Shiriffes and Officers.

sp.speaker: Ski.
sp.p: Now fortune help or never: they come, and ye were a Prince as ye say ye are, ye would be ashamed to abuse a poor servant thus, but and if you were not of the blood Royal, I would break the neck of ye down the stayres, so would I, I would teach you to hurt prentices.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Who hurt thee fellow?

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: Prince devil or his dam, Prince Iohn they call him.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: Gloucester I hope.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: I doubt not but it is, Skink.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Where is he?

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: Up them stayres, take heed of him.
He is, in the Crown.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Alas poor fellow, he hath crowned thee shrewdly.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: In recompense, if it be him I seek,
I will give thee his whole head to tread upon,.
Follow me brother, come old Falconbridge,
Keep the stairs Sheriffs, you see it waxeth dark,
Take heed he slip not by you.

sp.speaker: Ski.
sp.l: Hang yourselves, this darkness shall convey me out, of doors
I will swim the Thames, but I will attain Black-heath,
London farewell, curse Iohn, rave Falconbridge,
Skink scapes you all by twilight's privilege.
Where is he? lights, bring lights, drag out that boy.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: This is my cloak, my hat, my rapier,
And either it was Skink or Gloucester.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.l: I know not who it was sir, he said he was Prince Iohn, he took away my apron and a pottle pot with him, and all too bloodied his head and face.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: We met him, by Saint Anthony, we met him.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: The fire of Saint Anthony confound
This changing counterfeit whatsoever he be.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: It makes me laugh at envious greediness,
Who feeds upon her own hearts bitterness.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Sirrah you that were born to cry anon,
What other copesmates have you in the house?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: Sir, my Masters guess be none of my copesmates,

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Well your guess, can ye guess who they be?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: Marry here is a pursuivant, that this Gentleman sir Richard Falconbridge left sick even now.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Marry of God did I, thou living knave?

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: I am a poor boy sir, your worship may say your pleasure, our maids have had a foul hand with him, you said he would be sick: so he is with a witness.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Look about Falconbridge, here is work for you,
You have some evil Angel in your shape,
Go sirrah, bring us forth that Pursuivant?

div1.stage: Enter two leading the Purseuant sicke.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Gloucester, thou wilt be too too venturous,
Thou dost delight in those odd humours so,
That much I fear they will, be thy overthrow.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.l: O O O not too fast; O I am sick, O very sick.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: What picture of the pestilence is this?

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: A poor man sir, a poor man sir: down I pray ye, I pray let me sit down. A sir Richard, sir Richard, a good sir Richard: what have I deserved to be thus dealt with all at your worships hands? ah ha, ah, ah.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: At my hands knave? at my hands paltry knave?

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.l: And I should be brought to my book oath sir:
What Ieffrey?

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.l: Anon, anon.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: A plague upon your Ieffring, is your name Ieffrey?

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.l: Aye if it please you sir.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Why gentle Ieffrey then stay you awhile,
What can you say, if you come to your book?

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: If I be posed upon a book sir, though I be a poor prentice, I must speak the truth, and nothing but the truth sir.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: And what is, your truth sir?

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.l: O, O my heart.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.l: Marry sir this Knight, this man of worship.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Well, what of me? what did my worship do?

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.l: Marry ye came into the Bell, our room next the Bar, with this honest man as I take it.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: As thou takest it?

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.l: O sir it is too true, too true, too true O Lord.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: And there he called for a pint of Sack, as good Sack (I will be posed upon all the books that ever opened and shut) as any is in all Christendom.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Body of me, I come and call for Sack?

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.l: O ye did, ye did, ye did, O O.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Well forward sirrah.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Gloucester hath done this jest.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: And you called then for Sugar sir, as good Sugar and as wholesome, as ever came in any cup of Sack: you drunk to this man, and you do well God be thanked, but he no sooner drunk:

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.l: But I, but I, but I, O my head, O my heart.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: I cannot choose but smile at these conceits.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: I am mad, and yet I must laugh at Falconbridge:
Brother, look how sir Richard acts his rage?

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: I came? I call? the man is like to die,
Practise by th'emasse, practise by the marry God,
Iohn loves me not, Prince Richard loves my wife,
I shall be charged here, for a poisoned knave,
Practise by the Lord, practise I see it clear.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.l: And more Sir Richard, O Lord O Sir Richard,

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: What more? what hast thou more? what practise more?

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.l: O my box, my box, with the Kings arms, O my box,
O my box, it cost me, O Lord every penny O, my box,

sp.speaker: Rcih.
sp.l: And what of your box sir.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: Marry sir it is, lost, and it is well known my Master keeps no thieves in his house, O there was none but you and he.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: O then belike thou thinkest I had his box,

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: O sir Richard I will not, O Lord I will not charge you for all the world, but, but, but for the warrant the old King signed to reprieve the Porter of the fleet, O God, O God!

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: The Porter of the Fleet, the old king signed,

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.l: I my good Lord, o, o,

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Is he reprieved then?

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.l: No my Lord, O sir Richard took it from me with his own hand, O.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Here is a device to bring me in contempt
With the old King, that I ever loved,
princes and Sheriff, you can witness with me,
That I have been with you, this afternoon,,
Only with you, with nobody but you,
And now a fellow whom the King would save,
By a reprieve, this fellow says is hanged,

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: If thou hadst done it, I would have justified it,
But Richard I conceit this jest already,
This mad mate Skink, this honest merry knave,
Meeting this Pursuivant, and hearing tell
He had a warrant to reprieve a slave,
Whom we would hang: stole it away from him.
This is sure the Jest, upon my life it is,

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.l: O but my warrant, how shall I do? O,

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: But look about you, hot brained brother Iohn,
And I believe you will, find it otherwise,
Gloucester hath got the warrant in disguise,
And saved the fellow you so fain would hang.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: No, no, how say you Master Sheriff, is he not hanged?

sp.speaker: Shi.
sp.l: My Lord, the gibbet was set up by noon
In the old Bailey, and I charged my men,
If I return not, though it were by Torch light,
To see him executed ere they come.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: I am greedy to hear news.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Robbed of my chain, out-faced I had a sword,
Accused of poisoning, cozenage, seeking blood?
Not to be borne: it is intolerable.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Sir Richard, I prithee have some patience.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: I will to Blacke-heath, talk not of patience,
It is intolerable, not to be borne.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: It is intolerable not to be borne,
A warrant brother, Falconbridge a warrant?

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: I saw no warrant, I defy you all.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: A slave, a Pursuivant, one winter born.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: I care not for thee that winter born.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.l: O it is I sir, that is my warrant.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Is it you? you rogue, you drunkard; ye are cheated,
And we are cheated of the prisoner,
Out dog, dog.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.l: O O O O my Lord.

sp.speaker: Shi.
sp.l: Have patience and we will have a privy search.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Go hang ye block-heads, get ye from my sight,
O would I were a Basilisk, to kill
These glare eyed villains.

sp.speaker: Shir.
sp.l: Come away let us leave him.
We have a warrant let him do his worst.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: I will to Blockhead, I will to the holy Hermit,
There shall I know not only these deceivers,
But how my wife plays fast and loose with Richard.
Ha, I shall fit them, I will tickle them,
I will do it, I will hence, I will to the Heath amain,

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: There shall I know, where this damned Gloucester is,
I will have the Devils roused to find that Devil,
Or else I will conjure the old Conjurer.
I will to Blockhead, and there with friends conspire,
But I will have Gloucester's head my hearts desire.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Would mad Earl Robyn saw these humorists
It would feed him fat with Laughter; O it would fit him,
Where ever he is, I know the bare conceit
Is better to him than his daintiest food,
Well, and it fits me well, now I have time,
To court my Lady Falconbridge at leisure,
Love I implore thy aid fair Cipria,
Thou seaborne mother at affections ring,
Shine brightly in thy sphere, that at my star,
My planet thou of all lights most beauteous,
Be thou to my desires Auspicious.

div1.stage: Enter Robin Hood en the Lady Faukenbridges gowne, night attire on his head.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: O for this Lady, was never poor Gentleman troubled with Gentlewoman as I am with myself, my Lady Falconbridge hath fitted me a turn, here I am visited with sleeveless errands and with asking for this thing Madam and that thing Madam, that they make me almost mad in earnest. whoop here is another Client.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Here is my Lady Rawfords Page attends to speak with your Ladyship.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: I pray ye bid her Lordships Page come into my
Ladyship: well Robin Hood, part with these petticoats,
And cast these loose devices from thy back,
I will never go more untrussed, never be kerchief.
Never have this ado, with what do you lack?

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.l: Madam my Lady greets your honour kindly,
And sends you the first grapes of her young vine.

sp.speaker: Rob.
Pa.
sp.l: No forsooth, Madam he is upon the green Jesting with a stammerer, one Redcap.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: It is a lewd fellow, pray bid him come in youth, I will give him his welcome at the door: commend me to your Lady, I pray ye heartily.
sp.p: Humphrey, I marvel where sir Richard is so late? truly, truly he does not as beseems a gentleman of his calling, pray let some go forth to meet him on the green, and send in that blockhead Blocke.

div1.stage: Enter Redcap and Blocke after him.

sp.speaker: Bloc.
sp.l: Will ye tell tales ye ass, will ye?

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.l: I will tell your Lady or I would to God we were hanged else, as my father should have been.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Now what is, the matter there I pray you? what company have you there in gods name? where spend you the day I pray?

sp.speaker: Bloc.
sp.l: Why where you gave me leave, at the gallows I was, no farther.

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.l: and you be his Lady, you are the Lady falconbridge, the Earl of gloucester sister.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: I am so fellow.

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.l: your man Block here, does no-nothing but flout me, and cries run Redcap and see your father hanged. I shall go near to make murder and he use it.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Well sirrah, leave your mocking you were best, I will bob your beetle he and if you mock him.

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.l: He is, run Redcap.

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.l: law Madam.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Away ye saucy fool, go wait within.

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.l: Run Redcap, run Redcap.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Art thou the Porters son, that was condemned about my brother Gloucester?

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.l: Aye God be with ye, I am the Porter's son, I must run to seek your brother.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Well drink that fellow, if thou find my brother be not too violent, and I will reward thee.

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.l: I th-th-thank ye heartily, and I had not been cozened with Skink, I had no need of these jaunts, for Gloucester was safe enough.

div1.stage: Enter Blocke and the Porter with his cloake muffled.

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.l: Ah farewell Redcap.

sp.speaker: Red,
sp.l: Fare well and be hang.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: You will never leave your knavery, who is there more?

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.l: One Madam that hath commendations to you from your brother.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Comest thou from Gloucester? thou art welcome friend

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.p: O it is, one of the kindest Ladies (though she will, now and then have about with Block) that ever breathed and she had been in her mood now, Redcap would have made her such sport as it a past.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Will you make sport and see who knocks again?

sp.speaker: Bl.
sp.l: Our gates are like an Anvil, from four to ten, nothing but nice a knock upon it.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Will you be gone sir? honest friend I am glad
My brother Gloucester got thy liberty,
Whose flight was cause of thy captivity:
Nor shall there be in us such negligence,
Though thou have lost thy Office and thy house,
But we will, see thee better far provided,
Than when thou wert porter in the Fleet.

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.l: Madam your old friend Prince Richard,
All alone, making moan, fetching many a grievous groan.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Prince Richard come so late? lights to his chamber,
Sirrah, in any case say I am sick.

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.l: Very sick, sick and like to die: I will sing it and you will.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Away ye knave, tell him, in the morning
I will humbly wait upon his excellence.

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.l: That is all his desire to have ye lowly and humble, and it is a courteous thing in a Lady.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Hence, or else I will, set you hence: go in good friend.
Come Lady Falconbridge, it is, time to come,
Robin can hold out no longer I see,
Hot wooers will be tempters presently.

sp.speaker: Sk.
sp.l: Now holy Skink in thy religious weed.
Look out for purchase, of thy wonted clients:
Warrants quoth you, I was fairly warranted,
Young Robin Hood the Earl of Huntington,
Shall never fetch me more unto his Prince.
sp.stage: Enter Ladie Faukenbridge in Merchants wiues attyre.
sp.l: But pauca verba Skink, a prize, a prize,
By-th'-mass a pretty girl, close Hermit close,
Over-hear if thou canst, what she desires,
For so my cunning and my credit spreads.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: See how affection arms my feeble strength,
To this so desperate journeying all alone,
While Robin Hood young Earl of Huntington,
Plays Lady Falconbridge for me at home.

sp.speaker: Ski.
sp.l: What mystery is this? the Lady Falconbridge,
It is she, sweet fortune thou hast sent her well,
I will entice this morsel to my Cell:
Her husband is jealous, I will give him cause,
As he believes, I hope it shall succeed;
Nay 'swounds it shall, she is mine in scorn of speed.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: By this broad beaten path, it should appear,
The holy Hermits Cave cannot be far,
And if I err not, this is he himself.

sp.speaker: Ski.
sp.l: What honoured tongue inquireth for the Hermit?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: What honoured tongue?

sp.speaker: Ski.
sp.l: I Lady Falconbridge,
I know ye, and I know for what you come.
For Gloucester and your husbands jealousy.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: O thou, whose eye of contemplation,
Looks through the windows of the highest heavens,
Resolve thy Handmaid, where Earl Gloucester lives:
And whether he shall live, and scape the hate,
Of proud young Henry and his brother Iohn?

sp.speaker: Ski.
sp.l: I will have you first in, I will tell you more anon.
Madam, they say bushes have ears and eyes,
And these are matters of great secrecy:
And you will vouchsafe enter my holy Cell,
There what you long to know, I will, quickly tell.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Stay here are strangers.

sp.speaker: Ski.
sp.l: A plague upon them, come they in the nick,
To hinder Raynald of his Foxes trick?

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Good day old Hermit.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: So to you fair Dame.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: By Elinor's gray eye she is fair indeed;
Sweet heart come ye for holy benisons?
Hermit hast thou good custom with such Clients?
I cannot blame your feats, your juggling tricks,
Plague juggle you.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Why curse ye sacred worth?

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Ill done in sooth my Lord, very ill done,
Wrong holiness: a very pretty woman.
Mock gravity; by the mass a cherry lip,
Ah it is, not well done, deride a holy Hermit?

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: I have it in my purse shall make amends.

sp.speaker: Ski.
sp.l: His purse and yours, shall make me some amends,
For hindering me this morning from the Lady;
For scaring me at Tavern yesternight,
For having back your chain, I will fit you both.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Hermit, a word.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: A word with you fair mistress.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Where lie your devils that tell all your news?
Would you would trouble them for half an hour,
To know what is, become of traitor Gloucester,
That in my clothes brake prison in the Fleet?

sp.speaker: Ski.
sp.l: No, it was Skink.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Come old fool ye dote.

sp.speaker: Ski.
sp.l: But hear me.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Hear him Prince.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: 'swounds who hears you? I will make your Lady graft ye for this work: but to your tale sir.

sp.speaker: Ski.
sp.l: Know thrice honoured Prince, that Skink did cousin Redcap of his clothes.
Gloucester did cozen Skink, and so escaped.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Well done Falconbridge?

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: My Lord, he tells you true.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: You find it on her lips: but forward sir.

sp.speaker: Ski.
sp.l: It was Skink in Gloucester's gown, whom you did visit,
That played at bowls and after stole your cloths,
While you went into the Lord Morton's chamber.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: This savours of some truth,

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: It is very like,

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: Well Falconbridge by heaven I will tell your wife,

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: She will much believe you: you will come?
Tell me of my wife: this evening fail me not.
My wife quoth you: I will send my wife from home,
Do, tell my wife prince Iohn, by my dear mother,
I love her too too well to like another.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: It seems so fox, O what a world is this,
There most sin reigns where least suspicion is,

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: You will come.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I will not fail, I warrant you,

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Hermit is all this true,

sp.speaker: Ski.
sp.l: Himself deliver not so much before ye sleep,
Root me from out the borders of this Realm.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Well by your leave sir Richard Falconbridge,
Hence free from fear, you will, melt you will, melt old man,

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Nay take her to you, she is a shrew I warrant,
I will to the holy Hermit, and inquire,
About my chain your sword, the Pursuivant
And other matters that I have to ask.

sp.speaker: Ski.
sp.l: You are welcome good sir Richard,

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Nay do not stand on terms, I am fire, all life,
Nor never tell me that I have a wife.
I do not mean to marry, ye think so,
But to be merry, you the manner know.
And you will have me, have me, appoint a meeting,
I will be your true love, you shall be my sweeting,
If you deny to promise, this is plain
I will have my will ere you get home again.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: most gracious Lord.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Tut tell not me of grace I like no goodness but a beauteous face.
Be therefore brief, give me your hand and swear,
Or I will away with you into the heath,
Neither shall Falconbridge nor Hermit help,
And what I do I will answer well enough.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Why, then my Lord.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Nay do not stand on then,
But tell me when my Lord shall have you Lady,
It is presently, I will, venture for a baby.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: This night at stepney by my summer house,
There is a tavern which I sometime use,
When we from London come a-gossiping,
It is the Hind.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Give me thy pretty hand.
Thou wild meet me at the Hind, I will by thy Roe,

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: One word is enough,

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Suffice then be it so,

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I will fit my old adulterer and your grace,
I will send the Princess thither in my place.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Prince Iohn, Prince Iohn the Hermit tells me wonders.
He says it was Skink that escaped us at the Tavern,
Skink had my chain: nay sure that Skink did all.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: I say go but to yonder corner,
And ere the Sun be half an hour higher,
There will the thief attempt a robbery,

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Who Skink?

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Will Skink?

sp.speaker: Ski.
sp.l: I Skink upon my word.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Shall we go seize upon him good Prince Iohn?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Nay we will have him that is no question.
And yet not hurt the honest rogue.
he will help us well in quest of changing Gloucester,
Hermit farewell. Lady keep your hour.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Adieu old Hermit: soon in the evening Lass,

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I will meet you both, and meet with both of you.
Father what answer do you give to me?

sp.speaker: Ski.
sp.l: Lady start down I must into my cell,
Where I am curing of a man late hurt,
He dressed, I must unto my Orisons,
In half an hour all will, be dispatched,
And then I will attend your Ladyship.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: At your best leisure father, O the life
That this thrice reverend Hermit leadeth here.
How far remote from mortal vanities,
Baits to the soul, enticements to the eye?
How far is he unlike my lustful Lord?
Who being given himself to be unchaste,
Think all men like himself, in their effects,
And injures me, that never had a thought,
To wrong the sacred rites of spotless faith.

div1.stage: Enter Skinke with a patch on his face, and a Faulconers lure in his hand.

sp.speaker: Ski.
sp.p: Hermit farewell, I will, pay ye or speak with ye next time I see ye. Sweet mouse the Hermit bids you stay here, he will visit you anon. Now Iohn and Falconbridge, I will match ye, and I do not say Skink is a wretch, a wren, a worm, when I have tricked them, Madam I will trim you. Commodity is to be preferred before pleasure. About profit Skink, for crowns for crowns, that make the kingly thoughts.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I am assured that man is some murderer,
Good Father Hermit speak and comfort me,
Are ye at prayers good old man? I pray ye speak,
What is here a beard? a counterfeited hair?
The Hermits ports? garments and his beads?
Iesus defend me I will fly this den,
It is some thieves cave, no haunt for holy men.
What if the murderer, (as I guess him one)
Set on my husband, tush Prince Iohn and he
Are able to defend them noble selves,
However, I will not tarry, I will away,
Lest unto theft and rape, I prove a prey.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: Yonder they are I will fit them, here is my ground:
Wa ha how, wa ha how, wa ha how?

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: I warrant ye my Lord some man is distressed.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Why man it is a Falconer.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Marry of me good fellow, I did think thou hadst been robbed.

sp.speaker: Ski.
sp.p: Robbed, sir no, he that comes to rob me shall have a hard match on it, yet two good fellows had like to been robbed by one tall thief, had not I stepped in: a bots on him, I lost a hawk by him, and yet I cared not to send another after him, so I could find the thief; and here about he is. I know he is squatted.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Sayst thou me so? we will find him by Saint Marry.
An honest fellow, a good common wealths man.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: There are caves hereabout good fellow, are there not?

sp.speaker: Ski.
sp.l: Yes sir, tread the ground sir, and you shall hear their hollowness, this way sir this way.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Help Falconbridge.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: O help me good prince Iohn.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.p: I will help you both, deliver sir deliver, 'swounds linger not: Prince Iohn put up your purse, or I will, throw poniards down upon your pate. Quickly, when? I am Skink that escaped ye yesternight, and fled the Fleet in your cloak, carrying me clean out of wind and rain. I broke the bonds and links that fettered your chain amity, this cheat is mine: Farewell I cannot stay, sweet Prince, old Knight, I thank ye for this pray.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Gods marry mother, here is a jest indeed,
We came to take, a thief takes us:
Where are ye good my Lord?

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: No matter where, I think I was fore-spoken at the teat,
This damned rogue served me thus? Gloucester and he
Upon my life conclude in villainy.
He was not wont to plot these stratagems,
Lend me your hand a little, come away,
Let us to the Cell again, perchance the Hermit
Is Skink, and thief, and Hermit all in one.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Marry-a'God then ten to one its so,
Well thought on Princely Iohn,
He had my chain, no doubt he had your sword.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: If there be now no Hermit at the Cell,
I will swear by all the Saints its none but he.

div1.stage: Enter Gloster in the Hermits gowne, putting on the beard.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: This accident hath hit thy humour Gloucester,
From pursuivant I will, turn a Hermit now.
Sure he that keeps this Cell is a counterfeit,
Else what does he here with false hair and beard?
Well howsoever it be, I will seem to be
The holy Hermit: for such fame there is,
Of one accounted reverend on this heath.

sp.speaker: Ski.
sp.l: I will fain unto my cell, to my fair Lady,
But Iohn and Falconbridge are at my heels.
And some odd mate is got into my gown,
And walks devoutly like my counterfeit,
I cannot stay to question with you now,
I have another gown, and all things fit,
These guests once rid, new mate? I will bum, I will mark you.

sp.speaker: Gl.
sp.l: What is he a-god's-name? he is quickly gone,
I am for him, were he Robin-good fellow,
Who is yonder the Prince Iohn and Falconbridge?
I think they haunt me like my genii ,
One good the other ill, by th'mas they pry
And look upon me but suspiciously.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: This is not Skink, the Hermit is not Skink:
He is a learned reverend holy man.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: He is he is a very godly man.
I warrant ye, he is, at his book at his prayers,
We, should have took you, by my hollydam
Even for a very thief.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Now God forfend such noblemen as you should guess me so,
I never gave such cause for aught I know.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Yet thou didst tell us Skink should do a robbery,
Appointed us the place, and there we found him,

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: And he felt us, for he hath robbed us both.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: He is, a lewd fellow, but he shall be taken.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: I had rather hear of Gloucester than of him.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Gloucester did cheat him, of the same gold chain,
That deceived Sir Richard Falconbridge.
He got your sword Prince Iohn: it was he that saved
The porter, and beguiled the Pursuivant,

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: A vengeance on him.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Do not curse good Prince, he is bad enough, it were better pray for him.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: I will kill thee, and thou bid me pray for him.
I will fell woods, and ring thee round with fire,
Make thee an offering unto fierce revenge,
If thou have but a thought to pray for him.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: I am bound to pray for all men, chiefly christians.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Ha ha, for christians, thinkst thou he is one?
For men: hast thou opinion he is a man?
He that changes himself to sundry shapes,
Is he a christian? can he be a man?
O, Irreligious thoughts,

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Why worthy Prince I saw him christened, dept into the font

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Then nine times like the northern laplanders,
He backward circled the sacred Fount,
And nine times backward said his Orisons,
As often cursed the glorious host of heaven,
As many times invoke the fiends of hell,
And so turned witch, for Gloucester is a witch.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Have patient Gentle Prince, he shall appear,
Before your Kingly father speedily.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Shall he indeed? sweet comfort kiss thy cheek,
Peace circle in thy aged honoured head,
When he is taken: Hermit I protest
I will build thee up a chapel and a shrine:
I will have thee worshipped, as a man divine,
Assure he shall come, and Skink shall come.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Aye that same Skink, I prithee send that Skink,

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: Send both, and both as prisoners incriminate
Shall forfeit their last lives to Englands state,
Which way will Falconbridge?

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Over the water, and so with all speed I may to Stepney

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: I must to Stepney too, and revile, and be blithe,
Old wink at my mirth, it may make amends,
So thou, and I, and our friends, may be friends,

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: With all my heart, with all my heart Prince,
Old Falconbridge will wait upon your grace,
Be good to Gloucester for my Marrians sake,
And me and mine you shall your servants make,

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Of that anon my pleasure being served,
Gloucester shall have what Gloucester hath deserved.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Why, that is well said, adieu good honest Hermit,

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Hermit farewell, if I had my desire,
I will make the world thy wondrous deeds admire,

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Still good, still passing good, Gloucester is still
Enures true hate, foe to Iohns froward will.
No more of that for them in better time,
If this same Hermit be an honest man,
He will protect me by this simple life,
If not I care not, I will be ever Gloucester,
Make him my foot stole if he be a slave,
For Baseness over worth can have no power.
Robin bethink thee, thou art come from Kings.
Then scorn to be slave to underlings,
Look well about thee Lad and thou shalt see,
Them burst in envy that would injure thee.
Hermit I will meet you in your Hermits gown,
Honest, I will love you: worse, I will knock you down.
Kind friends, we have troubled Lady Falconbridge,
And either she is not willing to be seen,
Or else not well: or with our boldness grieved,
To ease these I have brought you to this window,
Knowing your are in music excellent,
I have penned a ditty here: and I desire
You would sing it for her love and my content,

sp.speaker: Musi.
sp.l: With all my heart my Lord.

div1.stage: Enter Robin Hood like the Lady.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Your excellence forgets your Princely worth,
If I may humbly crave it at your hands,
Let me desire this music be dismissed.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Forbear I pray and with draw yourselves.
Be not offended gracious Marrian,
Under the upper heaven, nine goodly spheres,
Turn with a motion ever musical,
In Palaces of Kings, melodious sound
Offer pleasures to their sovereigns ears.
In Temples, milk white clothed queristors,
Sing sacred Anthems bowing to the shrine,
And in the fields whole quires of winged clerks,
Salutes the morning bright and Crystalline.
Then blame not me, you are my heaven, my Queen.
My saint, my comfort, brighter than the morn,
To you all music, and all praise is due.
For your delight you for delight was born,
The world wold have no mirth, no joy, no day,
If from the world your beauty were away.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Fie on loves blasphemy and forgery,
To call that in, that is only misery,
I that am wedded to suspicious age,
Solicited by your lascivious youth,
I that have one poor comfort living,
Gloucester my brother, my hie hearted brother,
He flies for fear, lest he should faint and fall
Into the hands of hate tyrannical.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: What would you I should do?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: I would full fain, my brother Gloucester had his peace again.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Shall love be my reward if I do bring
A certain token of his good estate,
And after pacify my brothers wrath?
Say you will, love, we will be fortunate.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: I will.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: No more, I vow to die unblessed
If I perform not this imposed quest,
But one word Madam pray can you tell,
Where Huntington my ward is?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: I was bold to send young Robin Hood your noble ward
Upon some business of import for me.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: I am glad he is employed in your affairs,
Farewell kind fair, let one cloudy frown
Shadow the bright sun of thy beauties light.
Be confident in this, I will, find thy brother,
Raise power but we will have peace, only perform
Your gracious promise at my back return.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Well, here is my hand, Prince Richard that same night
Which seconds the day of your return,
I will be your bedfellow, and from that hour
Forswear the loathed bed of Falconbridge:
Be speedy therefore, as you hope to speed.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: O that I were as large winged as the wind,
Then should you see my expeditious will:
My most desire, adieu, guess by my haste,
Of your sweet promise the delicious taste.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Why so: I am rid of him by this devise,
He would else have tired me with his sighs and songs,
But now I shall have ease, here comes the Saint,
To whom such suit was made.

sp.speaker: Bl.
sp.l: My Lady Gentlewoman is even here in her privity walk, Madam here is the Merchant's wife was here yesterday would speak with ye; O I was somewhat bold to bring her in.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Well leave us sir; you are welcome gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.l: These women have no liberality in the world in them,
I never let in man to my Lady, but I am rewarded.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Please ye to walk sir? wherefore mumble ye?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Robin what news? how hast thou done this night?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: My Ladyship hath done my part, my task,
Lain all alone for lack of company,
I might have had Prince Richard,

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Was he here?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: He went away but now; I have been loved and wood too simply,
God rid me of the woman once again,
I will not be tempted so for all the world,
Come, will you to your chamber and uncase?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Nay keep my habit yet a little while,
Old Falconbridge is almost at the gate,
I met him at Blackheath just at the Hermits,
And taking me to be a Merchants wife,
Fell mightily in love, gave me his ring,
Made me protest that I would meet him here.
I told him of his Lady, O tut quoth he,
I will shake her up, I will, pack her out of sight,
He comes kind Robin Hood, hold up the jest.

div1.stage: Enter Sir Rich. Faukenbridge and Blocke.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Gods marry knave, how long hath she been here?

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.l: Sir she came but even in afore you.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: A cunning quean, a very cunning quean,
Go to your business Block, I will, meet with her.

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.l: Ah old Muttonmunger I believe here is work towards.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Do not believe her Mall, do not believe her:
I only spake a word or two in jest,
But would not for the world have been so mad,
Do not believe her Mall, do not believe her:

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: What should I not believe? what do you mean?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Why good Sir Richard, let me speak with you,
Alas will you undo me? will you shame me?
Is this your promise? came I here for this?
To be a laughing stock unto your Lady

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: How now Sir Richard, what is the matter there?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: I will talk with you anon, come hither woman?
Didst not tell my wife what match we made:?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I tell your wife? think ye I am such a beast?
Now God forgive ye, I am quite undone.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Peace duck, peace duck, I warrant all is well.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: What is the matter? I pray ye sir Richard tell me?

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Marry Mall thus, about some twelve months since,
Your brother Gloucester, that mad prodigal,
Caused me to pass my word unto her husband,
For some two thousand pound: or more perchance,
No matter what it is, you shall not know,
Nay ye shall never ask to know.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: And what of this?

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Marry the man is decayed,
And I believe a little thing would please her;
A very little thing, a thing of nothing.
Go in good Mall, and leave us two alone,
I will deal with ye as simply as I can.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Fox look about ye, ye are caught yfaith.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Deal with her simply, O ho; what kind of dealing?
Can ye not deal with her and I be by?

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Mary'a'god, what are ye jealous?
Ye teach me what to do: in, get you in.
O I have heard Prince Richard was your guest,
How dealt you than? In get you in I say,
Must I take care about your brothers debts,
And you stand crossing me, in, or I will, send you in.
Ha sirrah, you will, be master, you will, wear the yellow,
You will be an over-seer: marry shall ye.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Ye are too cursed (me thinks sir) to your Lady;

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Ah wench content thee, I must bear her hard,
Else she will be prining into my dalliances:
I am an old man sweet girl I must be merry,
All steel, all spirit, keep in health by change,
Men may be wanton, woven must not range.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: You have given good counsel sir, I will repent me,
Here is your ring, I will, only love my husband.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: I mean not so, I think today thou toldest me
Thy husband was an unthrift, and a bankrupt,
And he be so, tut thou hast favour store,
Let the knave beg, beauty cannot be poor.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Indeed my husband is a bankrupt,
Of faith, of love, of shame, of chastity,
Dotes upon other women more than me.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Ha do he so? then give him tit for tat,
Have one so young and fair, and loves another,
He is worthy to be cuckolded by the mass.
What is he old or young?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: About your age.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: An old knave and cannot be content with such a peate,
Come to my closet girl, make much of me,
We will appoint a meeting place some twice a week,
And I will maintain thee like a Lady, ha?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: O but you will forget me presently,
When you look well upon your Ladies beauty.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Who upon her? why she is a very dowdy,
A dishclout, a foul Lipsey unto thee,
Come to my closet lass, there take thy earnest
Of love, of pleasure and good maintenance.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I am very fearful.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Come fool never fear I am Lord here, who shall disturb as then?
Nay come, or by the rood I will make you come,

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Help Madam Falconbridge for gods sake.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: How now, what meanest?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Help Gentle Madam help,

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: How now what ailest thou?

sp.speaker: Bloc.
sp.l: Nay and it be a woman, never fear my master Madam

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Why speakest thou not, what ailest thou?

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Why nothing, by the rood nothing she ails.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: O Madam this vile man would have abused me,
And forcest me to his closet,

sp.speaker: Rob,
sp.l: Ah old cole, now look about, you are catched,

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Call in your fellows blocke,

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Do not thou knave,

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Do or I will crack your crown,

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.l: Nay I will do it, I know she means to shame you.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Why Mall wilt thou believe this paltry woman?
Housewife I will have you whipped for slandering me.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: What Lecher, no she is an honest woman,
Her husband is well known, all the household knows.

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.l: Here is some now, to tell all the town your mind,

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Before ye all I must sure complain,
You see this wicked man, and ye all know
How oft he hath bin Jealous of my life,
Suspecting falsehood being false himself;

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.l: O master, O master,

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: She slanders me. she is a cozening quean,
Fetch me the Constable, I will have her punished,

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: The Constable for me fie, fie upon ye.
Madam do you know this ring?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: It is sir Richards.

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.l: O Aye, that is my masters too sure.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Aye marry, I did lend it to the false drab
To fetch some money for that bankrupt knave
Her husband, that lies prisoner in the Fleet.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: My husband bankrupt? my husband in the Fleet prisoner?
No, no, he is as good a man as you.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Aye that he is, and can spend pound for pound
With thee yfaith, wert richer than thou art,
I know the gentleman.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Nay Madam he is hard by, there must be Revels at the Hind tonight;
Your copesmate there, Prince Iohn.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: There is a hot youth.

sp.speaker: Bl.
sp.l: O, a fierce Gentleman.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: He was fierce as you, but I have matched him,
The Princess shall be there in my attire.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: A plaguey crafty quean, mary'a'god
I see Prince Iohn, courted as well as I,
And since he shall be mocked as well as I,
It is some contentment.

sp.speaker: Bl.
sp.l: Mass he droops, fellow Humphrey, he is almost taken,
Look about ye old Richard?

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Hence knaves, get in a little, prithee Mall
Let thou and I and she, shut up this matter.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Away sirs, get in.

sp.speaker: Bl.
sp.l: Come, come let us go, he will, be baited now, farewell old Richard.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Now sir, what say you now?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Marry sweet Mall I say I met this woman, liked her, loved her,
For she is worthy love I promise thee;
I say I courted her: tut make no brawl
Twixt thou and I, we will have amends for all.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Had I done such a trick, what then? what then?

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Ah prithee Mall, tut bear with men.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Aye, we must bear with you; you will be excused,
When women undeserved are abused.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Nay do not weep, pardon me gentle Lady,
I know thee virtuous, and I do protest,
Never to have an evil thought of thee.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Aye, Aye, ye swear, who is that that will believe ye?

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Now by my holy dam and honest faith,
This Gentlewoman shall witness what I swear.
Sweet Duck a little help me?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Trust him Madam.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: I will be kind, credulous, constant ever,
Do what thou wilt, I will, be suspicious never.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: For which I thank noble Falconbridge.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Body of me who is this? young Huntington?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: And I your Lady whom you courted last,
Ye looked about you ill, fox we have caught ye,
I met ye at Blackheath, and ye were hot.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: I knew thee Mall, now by my sword I knew thee,
I winked at all, I laughed at every jest.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Aye, he did wink, the blind man had an eye.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Peace Robin, thou art once be a man as I.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Well, I must bear it all.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: come, and ye bear, it is but your office, come forget sweet Mall.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I do forgive it and forget it sir.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Why that is well said, that is done like a good girl:
Ha sirrah, ha you matched me pretty Earl?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: I have, ye see sir I must unto Blackheath,
In quest of Richard, whom I sent to seek
Earl Gloucester out, I know he is at the Hermits;
Lend me your Coach; I will shift me as I ride,
Farewell sir Richard.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Farewell Englands pride, by the matins Mall it is a pretty child;
Shall we go meet Iohn? shall we go mock the Prince?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: We will.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: O then we shall have sport anon,
Never wear yellow Mall, it was but a trick,
Old Falconbridge will still be a mad Dicke.

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.l: Do ye say father Hermit, that Gloucester is about this Heath?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: He is upon this Heath Son look about it,
Run but the compass, thou shalt find him out.

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.l: run? I will, run the compass of all Kent but I will find him out, my father (where ever he lays his head) dare never come home I know, till he be found.

sp.speaker: Gl.
sp.l: Well thou shalt find him, knowest thou who is a hunting?

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.l: Marry it is the Earls of Lancaster and Leicester. farewell father, and I find Skink or gloucester, I will give thee the price of a penny pudding for thy pains.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Adieu good friend: this is sure the fellow
I sent on message from the Parliament.
The Porters son, he is still in quest of me,
And Skink that cozened him of his red cap.
sp.stage: Enter Richard like a Seruing man.
sp.l: But look about thee Gloucester, who comes yonder?
O a plain serving-man, and yet perhaps his bags are lined,
And my purse now grows thin: if he have any I must share with him.
And who is on yond side? O it is my Hermit,
Hath got his other suit since I went forth.

sp.speaker: Sk.
sp.l: Sbloud yonder is company, I will, back again,
Else I would be with you counterfeit,
I will leave the rogue till opportunity,
But never eat till I have quit my wrong.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: I saw two men attend like holy Hermits,
One is slipped away, the other at his beads,
Now Richard for the love of Marian,
Make thy inquiry where mad Gloucester lives.
If England or the verge of Scotland hold him,
I will seek him thus disguised: if he be past
To any foreign part; I will, follow him.
Love thou art Lord of hearts, thy laws are sweet,
In every troubled way, thou guidest our feet.
Lovers enjoined to pass the dangerous Sea
Of big swollen sorrow, in the Bark affection;
The winds and waves of woe need never fear,
While Love, the helm doth like a Pylate steer.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Here is some lover come, a mischief on him,
I know not how to answer these mad fools,
But I will, be brief, I will, mar the Hermits tale;
Off gown, hold Buckler, slice it bilbow blade.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: What is this? what should this mean? old man, good friend

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Young fool deliver else see your end.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: I thought thou hadst been holy and a Hermit.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Whatever you thought, your purse? come quickly sir?
Cast that upon the ground, and then confer.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: There it is.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Falls it so heavy? then my heart is light.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Thou wilt have a heavy heart before thou touch it,
Theft shrined in holy weeds? stand to it you are best.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: And if I do not, seeing such a pray,
Let this be to me a disaster day.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Art thou content to breath?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: With all my heart, take half thy money and we will friendly part.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: I will not cherish theft.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Then I defy thee.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Alas for pity, that so stout a man,
So reverend in aspect, should take this course.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: This is no common man with whom I fight,
And if he be he is of wondrous spirit,
Shall we part stakes?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Fellow take the purse upon condition thou wilt follow me.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: What wait on you? wear a turned Livery?
Whose man is your master? If I be your man,
My man's man's office will be excellent:
There lies your purse again, win it and wear it.

div1.stage: Enter Robin Hood, they breath, offer againe.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Clashing of weapons at my welcome hither?
Bickering upon Blockhead, well said old man,
I will take thy side, the younger hath the odds.
Stay end your quarrel, or I promise ye
I will take the old man's part.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: You were not wont young Huntington, still on Richards side

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Pardon gracious Prince I knew ye not.

sp.speaker: Gl.
sp.l: Prince Richard: then lie envy at his foot,
Pardon thy cousin Gloucester, valiant Lord,
I knew no common force confronted mine,
O heaven I had the like conceit of thine.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: I tell thee Robin Gloucester thou art met,
Bringing such comfort unto Richards heart.
As in the foil of war when dust and sweat,
The thirst of weak, and the Suns fiery heat,
Have seized upon the soul of valiance,
And he must faint except he be refreshed,
To me thou comest as if to him should come,
A perry from the North, whose frosty breath
Might fan him coolness in that doubt of death.
With me then meets, as he a spring might meet,
Cooling the earth under his toil parched feet,
Whose crystal moisture in his Helmet taken,
Comforts his spirits, makes him strong again.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Prince, in short terms if you have brought me comfort
Know if I had my pardon in this hand
That smite base Skink in open Parliament,
I would not come to Court, till the high feast
Of your proud brothers birth day be expired,
For as the old King as he made a vow
At his unlucky Coronation,
Must wait upon the boy and fill his cup,
And all the Peers must kneel while Henry kneels
Unto his cradle; he shall hang me up,
Ere I commit that vile Idolatry.
But when the feast is past if you will befriend me,
I will come and brave my proud foes to their teeth,

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Come Robin, and if my brothers grace deny,
I will take thy part, them and their threats defy,

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Gramercy Princely Dicke,

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: I have some power, I can raise two thousand Soldiers in an hour,

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Gramercy Robin, gramercy little wag,
Prince Richard, pray let Huntington
Carry my sister Falconbridge this ring,

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: I will carry it myself, but I had rather
Had thy kind company, thou mightst have moved
Thy Sister, whom I long have vainly loved,

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: I like her that she shuns temptation
Prince Richard, but I bear with doting lovers,
I should not take it well, that you urge me
To such an office: but I bear with you,
love is blind and mad, hie to her boldly, try her;
But if I know she yield, faith I will defy her,

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: I like thy honourable resolution,
Gloucester I pray thee pardon my entreat,

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: it is men's custom; part part Gentle Prince,
Farewell good Robin this gold I will borrow,
Meet you at stepney pay you all tomorrow,

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Adieu Gloucester,

sp.speaker: Gl.
sp.l: Farewell, be short; you gone, I hope to have a little sport

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Take heed mad Cuz.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Tut tell not me of heed,
He that is too wray never hath good speed.
sp.stage: Hollowing within, Enter Lanc. with a broken staffe in his hand.
sp.l: Who is this old Lancaster my honoured friend?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: These knaves have served me well, left me alone,
I have hunted fairly, lost my purse, my chain,
My Jewels, and been banged by a bold knave,
Clad in a Hermits gown like an old man,
O what a world is this?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: It is ill my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: He is come again, O knave it is the worse for thee,
Keep from me, be content with that thou hast,
And see thou fly this heath, for if I take thee,
I will make thee to all thieves a spectacle,
Had my staff held, thou hadst not scaped me so,
But come not near me, follow not thou art best,
Holla, Earl Lester, holla Huntsman ho?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Upon my life, old Lancaster a Hunting,
Hath met my fellow Hermit, could I meet him,
I would play rob thief, at least part stakes with him.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: Zounds he is yonder alone,
Skink now revenge thyself on yonder slave,
Znayles still prevented? this same Redcap rogue
Runs like hob-goblin up and down the heath.

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.l: Whop Hermit, ye have made
Redcap run a fine compass, have you not?

sp.speaker: Ski.
sp.l: I made thee run?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Yonder is my evil Angel, were redcap gone, Gloucester would conjure him.

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.p: Jesus bless me, whop two Hermits? I will caperclaw the one of ye, for mocking me, and I do not hang me: which is the false knave? for I am sure the old Hermit would never mock an honest man.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: he is the counterfeit he mocked thee fellow.
I did not see thee in my life before,
He wears my garments, and has cozened me,

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.l: Have you cozened the Hermit and made
Redcap run to no purpose?

sp.speaker: Ski.
sp.l: No he is, counterfeit I will tell no lies,
As sure as Skink deceived thee of thy clothes,
Sent thee to Kent, gave thee thy fare by water,
So sure he is false, and I the perfect Hermit,

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: This villain is a conjurer I doubt,
Were he the devil yet I would not budge,

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.l: Sirrah, you are the counterfeit, O this is the true Hermit, stand still good man at that, I will, bumbast you yfaith, I will, make you give the old man his gown.
sp.stage: Offers to strike, Gloster trippes vp his heeles, shifts Skinke into his place.
sp.l: God's lid are ye good at that? I will, cudgel ye for this trick.

sp.speaker: Ski.
sp.l: It was not I it was he that cast thee down,

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.l: You lie you rascal you, I left ye standing here.

sp.speaker: Ski.
sp.l: Zounds hold you stammerer, or I will cut your stumps.

sp.speaker: Gl.
sp.l: He is, for me he is weaponed, I like that.

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.l: O here is a rogue incarnate, help, murder murder.

div1.stage: Enter Lancaster & Huntsmen at one doore, Leyster & Huntsmen at another.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Lay hold upon that the euish counterfeit,

sp.speaker: Ley.
sp.l: Why here is another Hermit Lancaster:

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: I am the Hermit sir, that wretched man
Doth many a robbery in my disguise:

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: It is he that robs, he slanders me, he lies.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Which set on thee?

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.l: This fellow has a sword and a buckler.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Search him; this is the thief, o here is my purse,
My chain, my Jewels: o thou wicked wretch,
How darest thou under show of holiness,
Commit such actions of impiety?
Bind him, I will have him made a public scorn.

sp.speaker: Ski.
sp.l: Lay hold upon that other hermit.
He is a counterfeit as well as I,
He stole those clothes from me, for I am Skink,
Search him, I know him not, he is some slave.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Thou liest base varlet.

sp.speaker: Re.
sp.l: O God he has a sword too, Skink are you catched?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Villain thou shalt with me unto the Court.

sp.speaker: Ley.
sp.l: And this with me, this is the traitor Gloucester.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Thou liest proud Lester I am no traitor.

sp.speaker: Re.
sp.l: Gloucester? O brave, now my father shall be free

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Earl Gloucester I am sorry thou art taken.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: I am not taken yet, nor will I yield
To any here but noble Lancaster,
Let Skink be Leysters prisoner I will be thine.

sp.speaker: Ley,
sp.l: Thou shalt be mine.

sp.speaker: Gl.
sp.l: First through a crimson sluice, I will send thy hated soul to those black fiends
That long have hovered gaping for their part,
When tyrant life should leave thy traitor heart.
Come Lancaster keep Skink I will go with thee,
Let loose the mad knave, for I praise his shifts,
He shall not start away, I will, be his guide,
And with proud looks outface young Henries pride.

sp.speaker: Ley.
sp.l: Look to them Lancaster upon thy life.

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.l: Well I will, run and get a pardon of the King, Gloucester and Skink taken? O brave, run
Red cap and carry the first news to court.

sp.speaker: Ley.-
sp.l: Lancaster I will, help to guard them to the Court.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Do as you please.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Lester do not come near me, for if, thou do, thou shall buy it dearly.

sp.speaker: Ley.
sp.l: I will have thy hand for this.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Not for thy heart.

sp.speaker: Ski.
sp.p: Brave Earl, had Skink known thou hadst been the Noble Gloucester (whose mad tricks have made me love thee) I would have dyed Blackheath red with the blood of millions, ere we would have been taken; but what remedy, we are fast and must answer it like Gentlemen, like Soldiers, like resolutes.

sp.speaker: Gl.
sp.l: Aye ye are a gallant, come old Lancaster,
For thy sake will I go; or else by heaven
I would send some dozen of these slaves to hell.

div1.stage: Enter Prince Richard, Robert Hoode & Lady Faukenbridge.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Your travail and your comfortable news,
This Ring, the certain sign you met with him,
Binds me in duteous love unto your grace:
But on my knees I fall, and humbly crave,
Importune that no more, you never can have.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Nay then ye wrong me Lady Falconbridge,
Did you not join your fair white hand?
Swore that ye would forswear your husbands bed,
If I could but find out Gloucester?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I swear so?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Take heed, it is a high oath my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: What meanest thou Huntington?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: To save your soul, I do not love to have my friends forsworn,
She never promised that; you urge her with.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Go to, provoke me not.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: I tell you true, it was I in her attire that promised you,
She was gone unto the wizard at Blackheath,
And there had suitors more than a good many.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Was I deluded then?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: No not deluded, but hindered from desire unchaste and rude:
O let me woo ye with the tongue of ruth,
Dewing your Princely hand with pity's tears,
That you would leave this most unlawful suit,
If ever we live till Falconbridge be dead,
(As God defend his death I should desire)
Then if your highness deign so base a match,
And holy laws admit a marriage,
Considering our affinity in blood,
I will become your Hand maid not your harlot,
That shame shall never dwell upon my brow.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Aye faith my Lord she is honourably resolved,
For shame no more, importune her no more.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Marian I see thy virtue, and commend it,
I know my error seeking thy dishonour,
But the respectless, reasonless command
Of my inflamed love, bids me still try,
And trample under foot all piety.
Yet for I will not seem too impious,
Too inconsiderate of thy seeming grief,
Vouchsafe to be my Mistress: use me kindly,
And I protest I will, strive with all my power,
That lust himself may in his heat devour.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: You are my servant then.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Thanks sacred Mistress.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: What am I?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: You are my fellow Robert.

div1.stage: Enter Faukenbridge in his hose and dublet.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: What Prince Richard? noble Huntington?
Welcome, yfaith welcome, by the morrow Mass
You are come as fitly as my heart can wish:
Prince Iohn this night will be a Reveller,
He hath invited me and Marian.
Gods marry mother go along with us,
it is but hard by, close by, at our town Tavern.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Your Tavern?

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: O Aye aye aye it is his own made match,
I will make you laugh, I will, make you laugh yfaith;
Come, come, he is, ready, O come, come away.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: But where is the Princess?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: He is ready too, Block Block. my man, must be her waiting man,
Nay will, ye go? for gods sake let us go.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Is the jest so? nay then let us away.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: O it will allay his heat, make dead his fire.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Ye bobbed me first, ye first gave me my hire,
But come agods name, Prince Iohn stays for us.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: This is the word, ever at spend-thrifts feasts,
They are gulled themselves, and scoffed at by their guests.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Buffeled and scoffed, Skink, Gloucester, women, fools, and boys abuse me?
I will be revenged,

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Revenged, and why good child?
Old Falconbridge hath had a worser basting.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Aye, they have banded from chase to chase;
I have been their tennis ball, since I did court,

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Come Iohn, take hand with virtuous Isabell,
And let us unto the Court like loving friends,
Our Kingly brothers birthday's festival,
Is forth with to be kept, thither we will hie,
And grace with pomp that great solemnity.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Whether ye will,, I care not where I go:
If grief will grace it, I will adorn the show.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Come Madam, we must thither we are bound.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I am loath to see the Court, Gloucester being from thence,
Or kneel to him that gave us this offence.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Body of me peace woman I prithee peace.

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.l: God ye, God speed ye,

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Whether run you sir knave?

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.l: run ye sir knave? why I run to my Lady Falconbridge, to tell her Skink and Gloucester is taken, and are gone to the Court with Lord Lester, and Lord Lancaster.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Is Gloucester taken? thither will I fly
Upon wraths wings, not quiet till he die.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Is Gloucester taken?

sp.speaker: Red:
sp.l: Aye he is taken I warrant ye with a witness.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Then will I to Court, and either set him free, or die the death,
Follow me Falconbridge, fear not fair Madam:
You said you had the Porter in your house,
Some of your servants bring him, on my life
One hair shall not be taken from his head,
Nor he, nor you, nor Gloucester injured.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Come Mall, and Richard say the word never fear.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Madam, we have twenty thousand at our call,
The most, young Henry dares, is but to brawl.

sp.speaker: La:
sp.l: Pray God it prove so.

sp.speaker: Ric:
sp.l: Follow Huntington: sir Rich. do not fail to send the Porter.

sp.speaker: Fa:
sp.l: Blocke, bring the Porter of the Fleet to Court.

sp.speaker: Bl.
sp.l: I will sir.

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.l: The porter of the Fleete to Court? what porter of the Fleete?

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.l: What Redcap, run redcap, wilt thou see thy father?

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.l: My father? Aye that I would see my father, and there be a porter in your ho-house, it is my father.

sp.speaker: Bl.
sp.l: Follow me Redcap then.

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.l: And you were two to twenty Blocks, I would follow ye so I would, and run to the court too, and kneel before the King for his pardon.
Come away Redcap, run Redcap.

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.l: I run as fast as I can run I warrant ye.

div1.stage: Enter a Sinet, first two Horraldes, after them Leyster with a Scepter, Lancaster with a Crowne Imperiall on a cushion: After them Henry the elder bareheaded, bearing a swoord and a Globe: after him young Henry Crowned: Elinor the mother Queene Crowned: young Queene Crowned. Henry the elder places his Sonne, the two Queenes on eyther hand, himselfe at his feete, Leyster and Lancaster below him.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Herald, fetch Lancaster and Lester Coronets,
Suffer no Marquess, Earl, nor Countess enter,
Except their temples circled are in gold,
He delivers Coronets to Lester and Lancaster.
Show them our viceroys: by our will controlled
As at a coronation, every Peer
Appears in all his pomp, so at this feast
Held for our birth-right, let them be adorned.
Let Gloucester be brought in, crowned like an Earl,
This day we will have no parley of his death,
But talk of Jouisance and gleeful mirth.
Let Skink come in, give him a Barons seat,
High is his spirit, his deserts are great.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: You wrong the honour of Nobility,
To place a robber in a Barons stead,

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: It is well ye term him not a murtherer.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Had I mistermed him?

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Aye that had you Henry.
He did a piece of Justice at my Bidding.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Who made you a Justice?

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: I that had the power.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: You had none then.

sp.speaker: Ley.
sp.l: Yes he was crowned before.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Why does not Gloucester wear a Coronet?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Because his Sovereign doth not wear a Crown.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: By heaven put on thy Coronet, or that heaven
Which now with a clear, lends us this light,
Shall not be curtained with the veil of night,
Ere on thy head I clap a burning Crown,
Of red hot Iron that shall sear thy brains.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Good Gloucester Crown thee with thy Coronet.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Do gentle Earl.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: 'swounds do would I had one.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Do not I prithee keep thy proud heart still.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: I will wear it but to cross thy froward will.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Sit down and take thy place.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: It is the low earth.
To her I must, from her I had my breath.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: We are pleased thou shalt sit there, Skink take thy place among my nobles.

div1.stage: Enter Iohn and Jsabell with Coronets.

sp.speaker: Ski.
sp.l: Thanks to King Henries grace.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Iohn Earl of Morton and of Notingham,
With Isabell his Countess, bow themselves
Before their brother Henries Royal Throne.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Ascend your seats live in our daily love.

div1.stage: Enter Richard, and Robert with Coronts.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Richard the Prince of England, with his Ward
The noble Robert Hood, Earl Huntington,
Present their service to your Majesty.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: You are welcome too, though little be your love.

div1.stage: Enter Faukenbridge with his Lady, she a Coronet

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Old Richard Falconbridge, Knight of the cross,
Lord of the Cinque ports, with his noble wife
Dame Marrian Countess of west Hereford,
Offer their duties at this Royal meeting.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Sit down, thou art a neuter, she a foe,
Thy love we doubt her heart too well we know.
What suitors are without, let them come in.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: And have no Justice where contempt is King.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Mad man I give no care to thy loose words.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: O sir you are welcome, you have your old seat.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Though thou sit higher yet my heart is as great.

sp.speaker: Que.
sp.l: Great heart we will make you lesser by the head.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Ill comes not ever to the threatened.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: What are you two?

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.l: Marry if it please you I am Redcap.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: And what is your mate?

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.l: A poor Porter sir.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: The Porter of the fleet that was condemned.

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.l: No truly sir I was Porter last, when I left
The door open at the Tavern.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: O is it you sir?

sp.speaker: Ley.
sp.l: And what would you two have?

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.p: I come to require the young King of his goodness, since gloucester is taken, that he would let my father have his pardon.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Sirrah your father has his pardon signed,
Go to the office it shall be delivered.

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.l: And shall he be porter again?

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Aye that he shall, but let him be advised
Hereafter, how lets out prisoners.

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.l: I warrant ye my Lord.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: What hast thou more to say?

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.l: Marry I would have Skink punished for Conycatching me.

sp.speaker: Ley,
sp.l: Is that your business?

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.l: Aye by my troth is it.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Then get away.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Against Skink (poor knave)
Thou gets no right this day.

sp.speaker: Blo.
sp.l: O but run back Redcap for the Pursuivant.

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.l: O Lord sir, I have another suit for the Pursuivant, that has lost his box, and his warrant.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: What means the fellow?

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.l: Why the Pursuivant sir and the po-po-Porter.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: The box that I had from him, there it is.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Mary'a'me, and I was charged with it.
Had you it brother Gloucester? Gods good mercy,

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: And what have you to say?

sp.speaker: Bl.
sp.l: Nothing sir but God bless you, you are a goodly company, except sir William or my Lady will, command me any more service.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Away you prating knave, hence varlet, hence.

sp.speaker: Ley.
sp.l: Put forth them fellows there.

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.p: Afore I go I beseech you let Skink and Gloucester be looked to, for they have played the knaues too bad.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Take hence that stuttering fellow, shut them forth.

sp.speaker: Red.
sp.p: Nay I will run, faith you shall not need to bid him take me away, for Redcap will run rarely.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: The sundry misdemeanours late committed,
As thefts and shifts in other men's disguise,
We now must (knave Skink) freely tell thy faults.

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.p: Sweet King by these two terrors to mine enemies, that lend light to my bodies darkness: Cauilero Skink being beleaguered with an host of leaden heels, armed in ring Irish: cheated my hammerer of his Red cap and Coat; was surprised, brought to the fleet as a person suspected, past currant, till Gloucester stripped me from my counterfeit, clad my back in silk and my heart in sorrow, and so left me to the mercy of my mother wit: how Prince Iohn released me, he knows: how I got Falconbridge's chain, I know: but how he will get it again, I know not.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Where is it sirrah, tell me where it is?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: I got it from him, and I got Iohns sword,

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: I would it were to the hilts up in thy heart.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: O be more charitable brother Iohn.

sp.speaker: Ley.
sp.l: My Liege, you need not by particulars
Examine what the world knows too plain,
If you will pardon Skink, his life is saved,
If not, he is convicted by the Law.
For Gloucester: as you worthily resold,
First take his hand, and afterward his head.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Skink thou hast life, our pardon and our love.

sp.speaker: Ski.
sp.l: And your forgiveness for my robbery?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Tut never trouble me with such a toy.
Thou hinderest me from hearing of my joy.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Bring forth a blocke, wine, water and towel,
Knives, and a Surgeon to bind up the veins,
Of Gloucester's arm: when his right hand is off,
His hand that struck Skink at the Parliament:

sp.speaker: Sk.
sp.l: I shall bear his blows to my grave my Lord.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Son Henry see thy fathers palsy hands,
Joined like two suppliants, pressing to thy throne?
Look how the furrows of his aged cheek,
Filled with the rivulets of wet eyed moan,
Begs mercy for Earl Gloucester? weigh his gilt,
Why for a slave, should Royal blood be spilt?

sp.speaker: Ski.
sp.l: You wrong mine honour: Skink may be revenged,

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Father I do commend your humble course.
But quite dislike the project of your suit,
Good words in an ill cause makes the fact worse,
Of blood or Baseness, Justice will dispute,
The greater man the greater his transgression,
Where strength wrongs weakness, it is mere oppression,

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.l: O but King Henry hear a sister speak,
Gloucester was wronged, his lands were given away,
They are not Justly said. Just laws to break,
That keep their own right, with what power they may,
Think then thy Royal self began the wrong,
In giving Skink what did to him belong.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Hear me Son Henry, while thou art a King,
Give, take, prison, thy subjects are thy slaves,
Life, need, thrones proud hearts in dungeons fling.
Grace men today, tomorrow give them graves.
A King must be like Fortune; ever turning,
The world his football, all her glory spurning.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Still your old counsel Beldam policy,
You are a fit Tutoress in a Monarchy.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Mother you are unjust, savage, too cruel,
Unlike a woman: gentleness guides their sex,
But you to fury's fire add more fuel,
The vexed spirit, will you delight to vex?
O God when I conceit what you have done,
I am ashamed to be esteemed your son.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Base Richard I disdain to call thee brother,
Takest thou a traitor's part in our disgrace?
For Gloucester, wilt thou wrong our sacred mother?
I scorn thee and defy thee to thy face.
O that we were in field, then shouldst thou try,

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: How fast Earl Iohn would from Prince Richard fly
Thou meet a Lion in field? poor mouse,
All thy Careers are in a Brothel house.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Zounds boy.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Now man:

sp.speaker: Ley.
sp.l: Richard you wrong Prince Iohn.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Lester it were Good you proved his Champion.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Hasten the execution Royal Lord,
Let deeds make answer for their worthless words.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: I know if I respected hand or head,
I am encompassed with a world of friends,
And could from fury be delivered.
But then my freedom hazards many lives.
Henry perform the utmost of thy hate,
Let thy hard hearted mother have her will,,
Give Frantic Iohn no longer cause to prate,
I am prepared for the worst of ill,
You see my knees kiss the could pavements face,
They are not bent to Henry nor his friends,
But to all you whose blood fled to your hearts,
Shows your true sorrow in your ashy cheeks:
To you I bend my knees, you I entreat,
To smile on Gloucester's Resolution.
Whoever loves me will not shed a tear,
Nor breath a sigh, nor show a cloudy frown,
Look Henry, here is my hand, I lay it down,
And swear as I have Knighthood here it shall lie,
Till thou have used all thy tyranny.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Has no man heart to speak?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Let all that love me keep silence, or by heaven I will hate them dying.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Harry off with his hand, then with his head.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: By the redrood I cannot choose but weep.
Come love or hate my tears I cannot keep.

sp.speaker: Que.
sp.l: When comes this lingering executioner?

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: An executioner: an executioner:

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Call none till we have drunk: father fill wine,
Today your Office is to bear our cup.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: I will fill it Henry.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: Dick you are too mean, so bow unto your sovereign, Gloucester learn:

sp.speaker: Gl.
sp.l: Kneel to his child? O hell! O torture!
Who would love life, to see this huge dishonour?

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Saturne kneeled to his Son, the God was fain
To call young Jove his ages Sovereign.
Take now your seat again and wear your Crown;
Now shineth Henry like the Midday's Son,
Through his Horizon, darting all his beams,
Blinding with his bright splendour every eye,
That stares against his face of Majesty.
The Comets, whose malicious gleams
Threatened the ruin of our Royalty,
Stands at our mercy, yet our wrath denies
All favour, but extreme extremities.
Gloucester, have to thy sorrow, chase thy arm
That I may see thy blood (I longed for oft)
Gush from thy veins, and stain this Palace roof.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: It would exceed gilding.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Aye as gold doth Ochre.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: It is well ye count my blood so precious.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Lester reach Gloucester wine.

sp.speaker: Ley.
sp.l: I reach it him?

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Proud Earl I will, spurn thee, quickly go and bear it

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: I will count it poison if his hand come near it.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Give it him Lester upon our displeasure.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Thus Gloucester takes it, thus again he flings it,
In scorn of him that sent it, and of him that brought it.

sp.speaker: Ski.
sp.l: O brave spirit!

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Bravely resolved brother, I honour thee.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Hark how his sister joys in his abuse?
Wilt thou endure it Hall?

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Peace good Marian.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Avoid there every under Officer.
Leave but us, our Peers and Ladies here.
Richard you love Earl Gloucester: look about
If you can spy one in this company,
That hath not done as great a sin as Gloucester;
Choose him, let him be the executioner.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Thou hast done worse then, like rebellious head,
Hast armed ten thousand hands against his life
That loved thee so, as thou wert made a King,
Being his child, now he is, thy underling.
I have done worse: thrice I drew my sword,
In three set battles for thy false defence.
Iohn hath done worse, he still hath took thy part,
All of us three have smitte our fathers heart;
Which made proud Lester bold to strike his face,
To his eternal shame, and our disgrace.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Silence, I see thou meanest to find none fit.
I am sure, nor Lancaster, nor Huntington,
Nor Falconbridge, will lay a hand on him.
Mother, wife, brother, let us descend the Throne
Where Henry is the Monarch of the West,
Hath set amongst his Princes dignified.
Father take you the place, see Justice.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: It is unjust Justice I must tell thee Son.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Mother hold you the Basin, you the Towel,
I know your French hearts thirst for English blood;
Iohn, take the Mallet, I will hold the knife,
And when I bid thee smite, strike for thy life:
Make a mark Surgeon, Gloucester now prepare thee.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Tut, I am ready, to thy worst I dare thee.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Then have I done my worst, thrice honoured Earl,
I do embrace thee in affections arms.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: What means thou Henry? O what means my Son?

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: I mean no longer to be lullabied,
In your seditious arms.

sp.speaker: Hen. wife.
sp.l: Mordieu Henry.

sp.speaker: Hen:
sp.l: Mordieu nor devil, little tit of France,
I know your heart leaps, at our hearts mischance,

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: 'swounds Henry thou art mad:

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: I have been mad; what stampst thou Iohn? knowest thou not who I am?
Come stamp the devil out, sucked from thy Dam.

sp.speaker: Que.
sp.l: I will curse thee Henry.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: You are best be quiet, lest where we find you, to the Tower we bear you,
For being abroad, England hath cause to fear ye.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: I am struck dumb with wonder.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: I amazed, imagine that I see a vision.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Gloucester, I give thee first this Skink, this slave,
It is in thy power, his life to spill or save,

sp.speaker: Skin.
sp.l: He is, a noble gentleman, I do not doubt his usage.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Stand not thus wondering, Princes kneel all down,
And cast your Coronets before his Crown,
Down stubborn Queen, kneel to your wronged King,
Down Mammet; Lester I will, cut off thy legs,
If thou delay thy duty: when proud Iohn?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Nay if all kneel, of force I must be one.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Now by my holydom a virtuous deed.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Father you see your most rebellious son,
Stricken with horror of his horrid guilt,
Requesting sentence fitting his desert,
O tread upon his head, that trod your heart.
I do deliver up all dignity,
Crown, Sceptre, sword unto your Majesty.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: My heart surfeits with joy in hearing this.
And dear Son I will, bless thee with a kiss.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: I will not rise, I will not leave this ground,
Till all these voices joined in one sound:
Cry, God save Henry second of that name,
Let his friends live, his foes see death with shame.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: God save Henry second of that name,
Let his friends live, his foes see death with shame.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Amen, Amen, Amen.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: Hark mother hark?
My brother is already turned Clarke.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: He is a recreant, I am mad with rage.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Be angry at your envy gracious mother,
Learn patience and true humility
Of your worst tutored Son, for I am he.
Send hence that Frenchwoman, give her her dowry,
Either not speak, to trouble my mild soul,
Which of this world hath taken her last leave:
And by her power, will my proud flesh control.
Off with these silks, my garments shall be gray,
My shirt hard hair, my bed the ashy dust,
My pillow but a lump of hardened clay:
For clay I am, and unto clay I must,
O I beseech ye let me go alone,
To live, where my loose life I may bemoan.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Son?

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Son?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Brother?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Brother?

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Let none call me their Son, I am no man's brother,
My kindred is in heaven, I know no other,
Farewell, farewell, the world is yours, pray take it,
I will leave vexation, and with joy forsake it.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Wondrous conversion.

sp.speaker: Fau.
sp.l: Admirable good: now by my holydam Mall passing good.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: He hath fired my soul I will to Palestine,
And pay my vows before the Sepulchre,
Among the multitude of misbelief.
I will show myself the Soldier of Christ,
Spend blood, sweat tears, for satisfaction
Of many many sins which I lament:
And never think to have them pardoned,
Till I have part of Sirria conquered.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: He makes me wonder, and inflames my spirits,
With an exceeding zeal to Portingale,
Which Kingdom the unchristened Sarisons,
The black faced Africans, and tawny Moors,
Have got unjustly in possession:
Whence I will fire them with the help of heaven.

sp.speaker: Ski.
sp.l: Skink will scorch them brave Gloucester
Make Carbonadoes of their Bacon fletches;
Deserve to be counted valiant by his valour,
And Ryuo will he cry and Castile too,
And wonders in the land of Civil do.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: O that I were a man to see these fights,
To spend my blood amongst these worthy Knights.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Marry aye me, were I a boy again,
I would either to Ierusalem or Spaine.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Faith I will keep England, mother you and I
Will live, for all this fight and foolery.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Peace to us all, let us all for peace give praise,
Unlooked for peace, unlooked for happy days.
Love Henries birthday, he hath been new born,
I am new crowned, new settled in my seat.
Let us all to the Chapel, there give thanks and praise,
Beseeching grace from Heavens eternal Throne,
That England never know more Prince than one.
